The police have recovered 11 automatic pistols with 7 live cartridges and a Toyota Corolla car from the accused," said Preet Pal Sangwan, ACP (crime). The weapons were reportedly brought to Gurugram in order to be supplied to criminals operating in the city. The police have also identified the criminals to whom the accused duo have handed the consignment, but didn't disclose the names for investigation reasons. "This is not the first time while the police have nabbed Kuldeep Singh, in 2018 Singh was arrested in a dacoity and arms act case, the case was filed against him at the Rajendra Park police station," Sangwan said. The police also suspect that while in jail he came in contact with illegal arms suppliers and once he was released, he began procuring illegal weapons from them with the intention of supplying to criminals in Gurugram. The accused used to procure the illegal automatic pistols from Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh for Rs 22,000 each. However, the police are ascertaining how much amount he charged from the criminals in lieu of the pistols. The market value of the pistols are Rs 50,000 each, according to police. "Earlier, Kuldeep was arrested in five cases under the arms act and other various sections of the IPC which were lodged against him in Gurugram, Bhiwani and Narnaul in Mahendergarh district in Haryana. We are also gathering information about Sachin the co-accused if he has any criminal history. Further probe in the matter is underway " Sangwan added.

head: Ranchi MLA lauds farm Bills, highlights features
desc: Senior BJP leader and former minister, CP Singh on Thursday attacked UPA parties including Congress for opposing the agriculture reform bills passed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi government. Singh, addressing a press conference at party office said, “Congress opposition to the agriculture reform Bill has exposed the grand old party. Entire nation has seen the double stands of Congress.” Singh said, “The Congress party has talked about agricultural reforms in its manifesto, but today they are opposing it. In 2013, Rahul Gandhi said that the Congress will exclude fruits and vegetables from the APMC Act in the governed states, but today they are opposing this change.” Targeting Congress party, Singh the 6th time Ranchi MLA, said that the Congress party did nothing to empower the farmers in the last 55 years. Lauding Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the Ranchi MLA said that the PM has done historic work for the development and progress of agriculture and farmers. In the UPA government the agriculture budget was Rs 12,000 crores which was increased to Rs 1.34 lakh crores. Singh claimed that Rs 92,000 crores have been transferred in farmers’ account in Kisan Samman Nidhi scheme. Highlighting some of the agriculture schemes launched by the Modi government, Singh said that under Prime Minister Kisan Maandhan scheme, provision of pension of Rs 3000 per month for 60 years of farmers has been made. The farmers have received double the minimum support price (MSP) in 7 years. Highlighting the MSP increase under NDA regime, Singh said during UPA regime the MSP on lentils was Rs 2950 per quintal which has been increased to Rs 5100 per quintal. The MSP of Urad dal has increased from Rs 4300 to Rs 6000; similarly the MSP of moong, arhar, gram, mustard has been increased drastically. The increase in lentils MSP has yielded procurement of pulses where 1.25 lakh metric tons of pulses were purchased between 2009-14 it has increased to76.85 lakh metric tons of pulses between 2014-19. Describing the Agricultural Reforms Bill as beneficial for the farmers, Singh said that the confusion being spread by the opponents is absolutely baseless and wrong. Farmers will continue to get the minimum support price, now with the One Nation, One Market policy, the farmer will now be able to sell his crop to anyone anywhere, the agreement will guarantee the farmers to get the fixed price. On Sunday, the Rajya Sabha passed two contentious key farm bills - Farmer’s Produce Trade and Commerce (Promotion and Facilitation) Bill, 2020, and the Farmers (Empowerment and Protection) Agreement of Price Assurance and Farm Services Bill, 2020) through voice vote despite ruckus created by Opposition members.

head: JMM blames Raghubar for teachers' agony
desc: The Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM) on Thursday said that the Jharkhandi candidates and their families have faced problems at present due to the irrational and wrong employment policy of the former Bharatiya Janata Party Government led by former Chief Minister Raghubar Das. People should take legal action against former Chief Minister because as the head of the then Council of Ministers, Das is fully responsible for this policy. On the High Court's decision on employment policy, JMM General Secretary cum Spokesperson Supriyo Bhattacharya said that the Government had the right to make laws for tribal and indigenous people in special circumstances on the advice of TSC in the Government of India vs Rakesh Kumar case. But, the Raghubar Government did not implement it. The then Government used only Para 5 of Article 5, due to which this planning policy could not stand in the Court. Targeting BJP legislative body leader Babulal Marandi, Bhattacharya said that it was for his vested interest that he sent six of his MLAs for the majority of the Raghubar Government. “The six JVM MLAs not only strengthened the Raghubar Government, but their own MLA Amar Bauri deceived the people of Jharkhand in the name of employment policy. The 1985 cut-off date and employment policy is completely irrational and unconstitutional,” he added. Bhattacharya said that the employment policy issued by the Raghubar Government in July 2016 in the name of employment and teachers’ recruitment was a completely fraudulent document. “On the recommendation of the committee headed by the then Minister Amar Bauri, an employment policy was announced under Article 309 under Para 5 of Schedule 5 of the Constitution. Under this, 13 districts of the State were kept under notified area and 11 districts under un notified area,” he added. The JMM leader said that the party had doubts about the manner, in which the Jharkhandi candidates were troubled by the High Court's decision on Monday. Due to the wrong policies of the Raghubar Government, thousands of candidates have lost their jobs however, this is not the first time, he added.  “At present the Raghubar Government is also responsible for the agitating Assistant Policemen. The Raghubar Government claimed to have given 75000 jobs in the last five years and it was included in the Guinness Book of Records. Employment fair was organized for this; agencies were invited on the expense of Government money. At that time also JMM said that it is fraud and the Government is doing so to dupe people,” said Bhattacharya. The party Spokesperson said that the then Government also misguided the Governor before doing so.” JMM has been saying from the beginning that the 1985 cut-off date in the local policy and the employment policy of the Raghubar Government is completely irrational and unconstitutional. This policy was introduced to cheat and fool people but the BJP, which has pat its back in the name of employment, only fools the people of the State,” he added.

head: PNS
desc: Attacking the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) led Central Government, Jharkhand Pradesh Congress Committee (JPCC) on Thursday said that the Government wants to end agricultural mandis across the Country to benefit its businessmen friends and also trying by abolishing Minimum Support Price (MSP) to save Rs one lakh crore. Addressing a virtual press rally JPCC In Charge, RPN Singh said that the three bills related to agriculture got passed by the Central Government by violating the parliamentary tradition, will eliminate 40 lakh mandis of the country, which will cause a lot of loss to the poor farmers, because 86 per cent farmers have less than five acres of land and 60 per cent farmers do agricultural work on less than 2 acres of land in the Country. “In such a situation, by abolishing the necessity of MSP in the new law, the farmers will be forced to bow before the corporate house. The BJP wants to implement the recommendation of the Shanta Kumar Committee's report, which states that the abolition of MSP can save Rs One lakh crore to the Central Government, the BJP-led Government is working on this agenda,” said Singh The party State In-Charge said that even though the Prime Minister has been repeatedly saying that the MSP will not be abolished, why the Government is not making provision in the law regarding it. Their intent is clear, he added. Singh recalled the Prime Minister's assurances which he had given in the past and said that Modi had also said earlier that everyone would get Rs 15 lakh, two crore youth would get jobs in a year, but it proved only a jumla. He said that the BJP is also trying to spread the illusion that the Congress party had decided to take a similar step, it is completely baseless, the Congress party has only taken up the problems of the far-flung farmers and necessary initiative in the direction was assured. Announcing the future plan of the party Singh said that against the decision of the Central Government, the party has decided to run a nationwide campaign till November.  “Under this, all the leaders and workers of the party will raise the voice of farmers through social media under the Speech Up for Famers on September 26. On March 28, after the dharna in front of the statue of Gandhiji at the State headquarters, the Raj Bhavan march will be organised and a memorandum will be submitted to the President through the Governor. On October 2, on the occasion of Gandhi and Shastri birth anniversary, senior party leaders will go to the districts to participate in the protest rally. On October 10, there will be a demonstration at the State headquarters. Apart from this, a nationwide signature campaign will be conducted from October 2 to 30,” he added.

head: Ranchi Police’s compassion wins hearts
desc: As a bus from Simdega district reached the Khadgada bus stand in the State capital at around 12:30 pm on Thursday, shrieks of a woman enduring labour pain were heard. The ToP In- charge ASI Bheem Singh present at the bus stand immediately rushed the woman to Sadar Hospital with the help of a medical team. Jyto Dungdung (20) who arrived at the bus stand in Ranchi broke down from acute labour pain as she disembarked from the bus.  “I was at the corona testing camp when I got information about the pregnant woman suffering from labour pain. Spreading a blanket on the ground, we initially helped the lady to lie down as she was unable to sit while the ambulance was on its way,” said Singh. The labour room is located on the first floor of Sadar Hospital. A team of nurses was waiting for the ambulance and the lady delivered the baby on the ground floor itself. Dungdung delivered a baby girl and was extremely thankful to the Ranchi Police for its prompt service. The lady also expressed immense gratitude for ToP In- charge Bheem Singh for showing that humanity is alive in today’s world. “It is a matter of great pride for us to serve the people and we shall continue to do our best under any circumstances,” added Singh who later visited the hospital to ensure that everything was carried out smoothly.

head: Rs 92L payout to family of man killed in road accident
desc: The Jharkhand State Legal Services Authority (JHALSA) through its first insurance Lok Adalat will award a compensation of Rs 92 lakh to family members of a policeman killed in a road accident two years ago. JHALSA executive chairman, Justice Harish Chandra Mishra along with other member secretaries will hand over the cheque of Rs 92 lakh to family members of the policeman at the country's first Lok Adalat to be held on September 26. The policeman, a resident of Jamshedpur was killed in a road accident near Chandil in 2018. The family members had knocked on the door of JHALSA to get their insurance claim. On the initiative of JHALSA, the insurance company United India Insurance agreed to pay the hefty compensation package to deceased family members. Apart from disbursement of Rs 92 lakh to family members of the policeman, family members of a Daltonganj resident, who too was killed in a road accident near Jamshedpur is to get an insurance claim of Rs 42 lakh. Justice Mishra said, “Insurance claims worth Rs 50 crore will be disbursed in 500 settled insurance claims and around 9000 pre litigation insurance claims.” Justice Mishra claimed that it is a big milestone for JHALSA as the judicial body is going to organize first of its kind insurance Lok Adalat. At Jharkhand High Court there will be three benches, while at district level two to four benches for hearing claims under insurance Lok Adalat. JHALSA for organizing the Lok Adalat had started preparations in July. JHALSA members had meetings with union finance secretary and representatives of various insurance companies for holding the Lok Adalat. Apart from insurance Lok Adalat, the JHALSA is also going to launch the mobile app and portal for giving legal aid to Jharkhand High Court. Supreme Court senior judge Justice NV Ramana will launch the mobile app and portal virtually on September 26. A function will be held at JHALSA office at Doranda which will be attended by Justice Mishra and other member secretary. JHALSA secretary, Santosh Kumar said that the mobile app and portal aims at providing legal services to common man in their finger tip. Santosh Kumar further said that though mobile app, applicants can get legal aid and even court fees for fighting legal cases. Interested candidates seeking legal aid after downloading the app have to submit his or her mobile number. The second step will be submitting the credentials which include name, address and other details of the candidate. The third step will be uploading legal details such as application, waqalatnama, lower court order and other court details. Once the applicants upload details in the app, the secretary will forward the application to the chairman of JHALSA. The JHALSA chairman after going through the case details will assign any lawyers from the list of panels of 91 lawyers for taking up the case.

head: DGP stresses upon inter-State cooperation to stop cybercrime
desc: Jharkhand DGP MV Rao on Thursday directed district police to work-out a composite plan to investigate cybercrime cases stating that nature and the emerging pattern of cybercrime needs more interstate cooperation. Rao said this while chairing a review meeting on cybercrime control at Jharkhand Police headquarters. The review meeting held through video conferencing was attended ADG (CID) Anil Palta, IG (HR) Naveen Kumar Singh, IG (Operation) Saket Kumar Singh, DIG Akhilesh Jha, SP (CID) Anjani Kumar Jha besides SP and SSP rank officials from districts attended the meeting. During course of meeting Rao sought from officials the five years record of cybercrime in their respective districts besides number of pending cases, details of cases where chargesheet has been submitted. He emphasised upon regular update of database of criminals. He said that once a cybercriminal is arrested mobile SIM cards are seized from their possession; police need to verify SIM card owner and whether or not SIM cards were procured on basis of fake documents. He said that in case of fake documents used in the procurement of SIM cards action must be taken against vendors and service providers. He also sought to know whether or not actions are being taken against vendors and service providers. DGP said that cybercrime is not restricted to any territory hence prevention and detection of crime and arresting of criminals can be ensured only through interstate cooperation. He said that Jharkhand Police has already facilitated Online Investigation Cooperation Request (OICR). This portal is meant to proactively seek cooperation requests from all states across the country, where victims might have lodged FIRs related to such frauds having some links in Jharkhand. It also intends to facilitate easy lodging of investigation cooperation requests by police of other states and law enforcement agencies in case the crime has any connection with Jharkhand. It will be the endeavour of Jharkhand Police to execute all the legal requests received via this online service at the earliest and communicate the action taken report to the requesting officer. He asked all districts to furnish a report about the number of investigation requests received on OICR. DGP said that police need to ensure quick disposal of cases and conviction of accused.

head: Labour Dept inks MoU with LSIPL
desc: A Memorandum of Understanding was signed between Labour, Planning and Training Department and LaborNet Services India Private Limited at Labour Commissioner's Office, Shram Bhavan here on Thursday. Under this MoU, the work of providing employment to the migrant workers of Jharkhand will be done through Labournet Services India Private Limited. Labour Commissioner, R N Yadav said on the occasion that the government will provide employment to the labourers not only in Jharkhand but in any State of the country. For this, labourers will be required to register on Samadhan portal. After registration, they will get a green or red card, take it and go to other places. This will give them the benefit of government-run schemes. Yadav said that labourers will be provided jobs, wages, medical, healthcare and living accommodation as per labour laws. Under this Covid 19 safety protocols will be ensured while housing and working for workers. Work will also be done to ensure safety, sanitation and drinking water facilities at both the workplace and the place of residence. Nursery, primary school and Anganwadis are also being arranged for the children of labourers, if the workers want to work with their children, then their children will also be looked after. On this occasion Umesh Prasad, Director Jharkhand State Labour Institute, Government of Jharkhand, Ram Kolavenu Labornet, Johnson Topno, State Manager, PHIA Foundation, Shikha, Helpdesk Lead, State Migrant Control Room, were present.

head: Sattriya dancer Sharodi Saikia shares journey of her dance career in ‘Baaton Baaton Mein’
desc: Renowned Sattriya dancer Sharodi Saikia featured in the 132nd episode of Baaton Baaton Mein. The talk show was featured on the Instagram live page.  A talk series ‘Baaton Baaton Mein’ is being held every day on Instagram. Hosted by renowned art critic Sunil Mishr, the series is being held for the art lovers. Hailing from Jorhat, Assam,Sharodi Saikia eminently represents the arts of dance and music of Assam. Sharodi Saikia, who learnt various dance forms in her formative years, found her passion in Sattriya dance. Her first lesson was in Manipuri dance under guru Rathin Singh, then she learnt Kathak in her teens. She received her training in the Sattriya tradition under Guru Raseswar Saikia Barbayan. She also received training in the art under Gurus Rameswar Khataniar Barbayan, Ghanakanta Borah Barbayan and Jagannath Mahanta, specializing in the Kamalabari style. She has also studied the Sitar under H. B. Dutta, Lipika Banerjee, and Nand Banerjee, and Hindustani vocal music under Nand Banerjee. While interacting with Sunil Mishr, she shared about her journey and shared the stories of her love for Sattriya dance of Assam.  Sharodi Saikia is a dancer, choreographer, teacher and music composer, has performed both at the national and international dance festivals including festivals organized by the Sangeet Natak Akademi such as Nritya Parva, Guwahati; Nritya Sangam at Guwahati and Raipur; and Purvottar Nritya Parv at Agartala.  She has also conducted workshops and lecture-demonstrations at various prestigious institutions and universities and has many dance choreographic productions to her credit. She established Rangayan – an academy of dance, theatre and music in 2003 at Guwahati, where she imparts training to young dancers and conducts research associated with the history and evolution of the Sattriya dance.  Sharodi Saikia has received several awards in appreciation of her work including the Devdasi Award.

head: Covid pandemic taught us to help each other: Archbishop
desc: Dr Leo Cornelio, the Archbishop of Bhopal said that the present Covid-19 pandemic is a common problem to be faced by everyone irrespective of any caste, creed or religion. The Archbishop said that the unexpected pandemic brought totally different mindsets, lifestyles and attitudes of the people for a new world order where the importance of God, and people are stressed in depth and not more on materialistic worlds. He also said that this Virus is teaching the people of our country many things. In the past we tend to differentiate people based on caste, creed and religion. But the Covid-19 brought unity in diversity and to look after each others needs besides recognizing the worth of human life.  This pandemic has given a new direction in the field of social, academic and spiritual sectors and made every one to face the crisis as one family, he added. Our country must rise against the forces that divide us. “Uniformity divides us while diversity unites us and every human being has positive forces to promote unity. Therefore every human being should improvise the positive characteristics that make them glow in the society he said. Children should be always taught good values that will help them to be the good citizens of tomorrow. “ he added. It should be noted that the church has always been promoting equality and human dignity in the society besides uplifting the values of Indian constitution by siding with the poor, marginalized, children, youth and the needy. The kingdom of God is to establish justice in all the spares of life, he said.

head: Heavy, light spells of rainfall witnessed across State
desc: State continued to witness spells of rainfall and intensity of rainfall has diminished on Thursday; State capital witnessed dark dense cloud, which failed to pour. Across the State pattern of rainfall with heavy and light spells were witnessed in the past 24 hours. On Thursday rainfall activities were less active and few regions witnessed rainfall. The Met department told that a low pressure over East Uttar Pradesh and adjoining areas is active and would induce rainfall while the system would turn east- north in the next 48 hours. The regions, which are likely to receive heavy rainfall according to the warning issued by Met department, are Rewa division and Annuppur, Shahdol, Panna and Chhatarpur districts. Thundery activities and thunder lightening warning has been issued for Rewa, Shahdol, Sagar, Hoshangabad and Bhopal divisions and Dhar, Ratlam, Dewas, Jabalpur and Katni. On Thursday till 5.30 in the evening Rewa recorded 2 cm of rainfall while other regions like Jabalpur, Satna, Sidhi, Khajuraho, Umaria and Mandla also reported rainfall. State capital recorded day temperature at 31 degree Celsius while night temperature at 23.2 degree Celsius. The day temperature is likely to record at 23 degree Celsius while the night temperature would be recorded around same level. In the past 24 hours the regions which recorded good rainfall(in cm) were Shyampur 15, Jaora 11, Chhatarpur 10, Tal 9, Badwaha 8, Shajapur, Sardarpur, Itarsi, Lateri, Prithvipur,  Jabalpur 7, Hata, Rajnagar, Sendhwa, Gunna, Khachraud, Gautampura, Sendwa 6, Kukshi, Suwasara, Ashok Nagar, Ashta, Panna, Gurh, Nagda 5 cm.

head: Help desk for people inaugurated at Indore RTO office
desc: A help desk based on the theme one stop solution is inaugurated at Indore RTO office by the senior citizens for the help of people who are coming to RTO office for different types of work. If any applicant comes at RTO office and if wants to get any information regarding his concerned work he can come to this help desk where he will come to know where the forms are available and where the concerned clerk is sitting also a map is also placed at the entry point which will indicate which section or which side of the building he has to go for his work also a wheel chair is made available at the RTO office for the help of handicap people. This help desk facility is started all over MP including Indore on the instruction of commissioner transport department Mukesh Jain and on this occasion RTO Indore Jitendra Raghuvanshi, ARTO Archana Mishra, ARTO Hridesh Yadav and ARTO Nisha Chouhan were present. On this occasion a plantation was also done by the senior citizen who inaugurated the help desk. A memento was also presented to the senior citizen Vijay Prakash Soni and also the lady who inaugurated the help desk.

head: Webinar on ‘Educational Thread of Self-Relient India under NEP’ held
desc: A webinar was organized under the joint aegis of the Department of Education, Commerce and Management of Rabindranath Tagore University on Thursday. The theme of this webinar was the educational thread of self-reliant India in the context of the new education policy. Keynote speaker of the webinar Prof. Roop Kishore Shastri was Vice-Chancellor Gurukul Kangri University, Haridwar, Uttarakhand. Prof. Shastri said that this new education policy is eternal. This policy systematically arranges from primary education to higher education and research. This education policy emphasizes practical education, dialogue and research from theoretical education. The country will definitely prosper with self-sufficiency. Vice-Chancellor of Rabindranath Tagore University Brahmaprakash Pethia explained the educational sources of self-reliant India based on various aspects and presented examples in the context of the new education policy. At the inauguration of the webinar, the university's registrar Vijay Singh said that the focus of the university is on cell development. The University has been continuously working for skill development and self-reliant India since its inception. The new education policy gives priority to skill development. If it is implemented smoothly, India will move towards the developed country. The webinar was organized by Rekha Gupta, Dean and  Kiran Mishra, Head of Department, Faculty of Education, Rabindranath Tagore University. The operation was conducted by Sangeeta Johri, Head of the Department of Management, and Deepti Maheshwari, Dean of the Department of Commerce.

head: Havells India enters refrigerator segment
desc: Havells India Limited, a leading Fast-Moving Electrical Goods (FMEG) company on Thursday entred into the refrigerator segment under its consumer durable brand - Lloyd. The company will also double the range with additional 25 models by Diwali this year. The refrigerator range is designed keeping in mind the modern kitchen aesthetics combined with energy saving features that adapt to the consumer lifestyle. The alluring transparent interiors of the range comes with an array of attractive fresh floral fascia design, which reflects refrigerators as a work of art that blends with your home décor. The refrigerators will be available in capacities ranging from 190 litres to 587 litres, and at an introductory offer price range from INR 10,000 to INR 84,990. While talking to media persons,  Shashi Arora, CEO, Lloyd said, “With the legacy of being known as a cooling expert over decades, Lloyd today is among the top 3 brands in the air conditioners segment. Today, we are introducing DC, Side by side, frost free range of refrigerators to complement other categories, in our attempt to make Lloyd a full-fledged consumer durable brand. Backed by our Make in India vision, we are going to produce all our refrigerators in the country enabling us to bring better quality and relevant customisations to our customers. The refrigerators launched today will offer class leading features in a wide array of capacities and price range through our strong network of 10,000 dealers and retailers across the country. Our range of refrigerators brings to our customers the benefits of even cooling that keeps all their food items including fruits and vegetables fresher for a longer duration. All this comes at a lower electricity cost due to the latest inverter technology deployed in the newly launched range.”

head: Police bust gang duping people for loans
desc: Cyber cell police have busted a three member inter-State gang involved in duping victims in the name of availing loan under Pradhan Mantri Scheme; gang members used to open an office at State level and would dupe victims. The victims were trapped using advertisements in the newspapers luring of loans under Pradhan Mantri Scheme and victims would be trapped through these advertisements. After the victim would agree it was asked to pay good amount in the name of processing and documentation. The victim was asked to transfer money in bank account which was later withdrawn. The accused were identified as Suresh Rajput, Sanju Rajput and Brijpal Rajput. The accused are of the same family and are residents of Sheopur Madhya Pradesh. During the investigation police found that the accused would introduce themselves as employees of microfinance company. The accused would provide mobile number of SIM card obtained using fake documents and when the victim would contact they would ask to deposit money for different reasons and later the victim was not able to contact the accused. None of the accused have studied till class 10. The accused have operated the racket for the past two years and duped scores of victims and duped to the tune of lakhs of rupees. The accused were operating 10 offices in different states from where the fraud was committed and victims were duped in the name of microfinance companies run by the accused.

head: Mobile rapid antigen testing vans for quick Covid detection
desc: The district health department has set mobile rapid antigen testing vans in motion in the city for quick detection of COVID cases, said an official on Thursday. About 9 testing vans equipped with testing kits, doctors, health staff have started moving to places specially containment zones to test people feared to be affected by the virus. The move will now enable symptomatic primary contacts, senior citizens and people with comorbidities to get them tested at their doorstep for a COVID test. "About 9 vans have been rolled in the city. The plan is to visit containment zones and detect cases quickly. The testing vans will now enable symptomatic primary contacts, senior citizens to undergo a Covid test at their door steps. If the throat and nasal swabs test negative, they will be sent to the nearest RTPCR testing facility for further determination. A mobile testing facility with a team of three people will be on standby in each of the city's zones to attend to symptomatic cases” said, East Singhbhum district surveillance officer, Dr Sahir Pall. He went on to add that they are requesting people to shed hesitation and fear and get themselves tested. The department is also conducting regular awareness drives to make people understand the importance of wearing masks and maintaining social distancing. Another official said the administration had previously directed random tests for some sections of society on priority. Now the plan is to target those who are regular in touch with the crowd. He went on to add that the administration has decided to test everyone in the district to prevent community spread of the disease. More tests would only help the administration to prevent further spread of the disease. He added it was the responsibility of the government as well as individuals to contain the spread of COVID19. Meanwhile, East Singhbhum has crossed 12500 COVID-19 positive cases in just four months. The active cases are around 9000. Trends in the city are suggesting that every second person who is being tested is positive for COVID-19. The recovery rate of the patient has also improved to 82 per cent in the district.

head: Chhattisgarh police bust IPL betting racket, 7 arrested
desc: Chhattisgarh Police on Thursday busted an IPL ‘satta’ (betting) racket operating inside two separate moving cars in the state capital and arrested seven persons. Raipur Senior Superintendent of Police Ajay Kumar Yadav told the Pioneer that Rs 12,000 in cash as well as betting records detailing transactions of around Rs 1 crore were seized from four of them. Those arrested were identified as Chhote Dewangan (53) of Bilaspur city and Gaurav Sabarwal (37), Mahendra Dewangan (37) and Mohammad Raees (24), all from Janjgir-Champa district. Police seized 10 mobile phones, a laptop and a car (CG-11, 8293). In another racket, the police arrested three persons, identified as Ritesh Govindani (26), Jitendra Premchandani (23) and Jagjeet Singh (22), all residents of Gudhiyari locality in Raipur. Police seized nine mobile phones, a laptop, a car (CG-04, 5554) and betting records of Rs 10 crore. The police conducted the raid on Wednesday night after getting a tip about the betting racket inside moving cars in the capital city on the match played between Mumbai Indians and Kolkata Knight Riders, the officer added. The arrested men said they were operating the betting racket inside cars as they did not get a room in any hotel or any other safe place due to the lockdown, Yadav said.

head: Be positive to keep good mental health amid Covid
desc: The Covid crisis has put people under immense pressure, adversely impacting their mental health. A positive attitude and regular exercise can help one keep calm, said Dr Manoj Sahu of Pt Jawaharlal Nehru Memorial Medical College in Raipur on Thursday.  “Students are unable to go to schools and colleges, people cannot move out, meet their friends or relatives and the fear of disease is making a serious negative impact on people’s mental health,” Dr Sahu said in a press release.  The symptoms of mental trouble caused by Covid-19 include irregular sleep, urge to cry, irritation, problem in taking rest, worry, feeling physically exhausted, weakness, guilt, problem in smiling or being happy and trouble in following a daily routine, Dr Sahu said. He said that some cases physical symptoms like stomach ache, dysentery, headache, body pain, decreased appetite or excessive eating, sweating or cold, shock or muscle cramps and increased heartbeat have been noted.  “In some cases, the patient has trouble focusing, has excessive negative thoughts and in a few cases they even lose interest in life,” Dr Sahu said. In these conditions, people should adopt a positive mental attitude and focus on solving problems with available resources, he said, adding people should take care of their food habits and do not hesitate to consult a psychologist if needed.

head: Dr Tripti Nagaria named in-charge Dean in CIMS
desc: Dr. Tripti Nagaria has been appointed as in-charge Dean of the Chhattisgarh Institute of Medical Sciences (CIMS) in Bilaspur. She was Professor-cum-HOD in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Pt Jawaharlal Nehru Memorial Medical College (JNMC). Among other appointments, Dr. PK Patra, who was Dean-cum-Professor in CIMS, has been posted as Dean-cum-Professor of JNMC in the state capital, a Chhattisgarh government order said on Thursday. Dr. Ramesh Murthy has also been appointed the in-charge Dean of Ambikapur Medical College, it added. Following a directive of the Chief Minister, the Dean of CIMS Bilaspur and the Civil Surgeon of Bilaspur were removed on Monday on charges of carelessness,      failure to follow Covid       control protocols as well as mismanagement.

head: Minister for regular monitoring of home isolated patients
desc: Chhattisgarh School Education Minister and in-charge Minister of Korba district Premsai Singh Tekam on Thursday told health officials to regularly monitor the Covid positive patients in home isolation. He also urged officials to strictly enforce the lockdown, an official press release said. “As per the instructions of the state government, a patient should be allowed to be in home isolation only if the house has sufficient space for other members as well. If such arrangements are not available, then the patient should be kept in Covid care centre or Covid hospital,” Tekam was quoted as saying. He told officials to monitor the patients in home isolation and see if they were consuming the medicines given to them. The Minister called for proper disposal of waste produced from the houses of such patients.  District Collector Kiran Kaushal told the Minister that currently there are 746 patients in home isolation in Korba district. Doctors are regularly monitoring their health. So far 12 patients were shifted to Covid hospital after their health deteriorated, the Collector said.

head: International seminar on sickle cell today
desc: An international seminar (webinar) on sickle cell -- ‘Advances in sickle cell disease’ -- will be held here today. The webinar is being jointly organized by the Sickle Cell Institute Chhattisgarh Raipur and the Indian Academy of Paediatrics. Dr Ifran Noor, Clinical Haematologist from Amsterdam University, will be the key speaker, Dr Arvind Neral, Director General of Sickle Cell Institute Chhattisgarh Raipur, said in a press release. Dr Noor is a renowned expert on sickle cell and his works have been published in various International journals, Dr Neral said. Dr Neral said Chhattisgarh is among the worst sickle cell hit regions of India and the numbers of sickle cell patients run in lakhs. Such seminars will help        doctors in Chhattisgarh get the    latest updates on this disease, Dr Neral said.

head: Rising dengue cases amid Covid in Haryana posing serious challenge to Health Deptt: DG Health Services
desc: With increase in the number of dengue cases being reported amid the current Covid-19 pandemic, the Department of Health and Family Welfare, Haryana is facing a tough challenge. Even as the State has around 20,000 active cases of Covid-19, dengue cases too have steadily increased from Gurugram, Faridabad, Sonepat, Bhiwani and other parts of the State. Both Covid-19 and dengue have symptoms such as high fever, headache and body pain. Till September 12, a total of 33 confirmed dengue cases were reported in the State but the number of such cases increased to 68 till September 24. Talking to ‘The Pioneer’ over the phone,  Haryana Director General of Health Services Dr Suraj Bhan Kamboj said that so far, no co-infection of dengue and Covid-19 cases has been reported from any part of the State. The Dengue test is being done free of cost in government laboratories and in all 27 Dengue Testing Labs are presently functional. In addition, dengue sampling has also started at Flu corners for suspected Dengue cases in district Bhiwani and Rohtak as mostly cases are reported from these districts. He further said that most cases of Covid-19 and dengue are asymptomatic (about 80 per cent), and in a setting of co-infection one disease might enhance the severity of the other.  “As Doctors often find it difficult to differentiate between the two diseases,  we have formed a set of protocols to help them. A new protocol has been developed to help medical professionals distinguish between Covid-19 and dengue, as both have similar symptoms. The protocols will also assist doctors to treat patients diagnosed with both the diseases effectively," he added.. When contacted, Dr Usha Gupta, director, Haryana Health services said that about 1,158 Dengue tests have been conducted in the State by the first week of September, 2020 apart from identifying dedicated beds for Dengue patients. Mosquito proofing of wards and beds is being done in Civil Hospitals. So far, 68 dengue cases have been reported from different parts of the State, which include 29 from Faridabad and 14 from Bhiwani. “Instructions have been issued to the authorities concerned in Gurugram, Bhiwani and others to ensure dengue cases do not increase in their districts. Moreover, Senior Health officers have been monitoring the prevalence Dengue effectively. To prevent mortality due to Dengue, new initiative i.e. the provision of free Single Donor Platelets (SDP) has been made for dengue patients admitted in Government Hospitals as some dengue patients with severe thrombocytopenia requires SDP for immediate recovery,” she added. Gupta further said that disease incidence is monitored on a daily basis and a vigil has been kept on the trend of dengue and other vector borne diseases. The Dengue situation is well under control in the State despite the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic situation.  She said, “We appeal to the general public to take up house-hold level activities to prevent mosquito breeding. For example, every Sunday should be considered as Drying Day i.e. emptying of water containers and check other probable mosquito breeding sites like cooler, overhead tanks, drum, discarded utensils, cups, bottles, tyres, pots, fridge tray etc., wear full sleeve clothes and use of mosquito repellents should be done.” Meanwhile, rising cases of dengue amid Covid-19 in Gurugram is posing a challenge to the district Health Department. The contagion of Covid-19 continued to report the highest number of 18,814 Covid-19 cases and second highest, 167 casualties in Gurugram district where maximum 29 out of 68 dengue cases have been reported. When contacted, Gurugram district health officers agreed that dengue was a challenge, especially when they were fighting Covid-19. “We held a meeting with all stakeholders to discuss steps to check dengue. Apart from municipal corporation teams that are also working on checking dengue, we have also constituted teams comprising two members each that have an assistant malaria officer (AMO). They have started visiting each sub-division for checking. Apart from that, we have divided the city into two parts and have deputed male supervisors and multi-purpose health workers, who will monitor the high risk areas,” an official said. He further said that the multi-purpose health workers and breeding checkers have been deputed to survey high risk areas from where cases are coming. They will search for the source of infection and work on source reduction. “Officials will check breeding of mosquitoes by using larvicides. They have also started checking coolers and would ensure that water is not accumulated in the city,” he said. A senior Government Health officer said that most people with dengue and Covid-19 could have mild illness and can recover at home; symptoms usually last a few days, and people tend to feel better after a week. However, both dengue and Covid-19 can cause severe illness that can result in death. The clinical management for people who develop severe illness with either of these two diseases is quite different, often requiring hospital-based care. Anyone of any age can develop severe illness with dengue or Covid-19. Both infections are more likely to cause complications in adults with underlying chronic conditions, such as diabetes and heart disease.  He further said, “Both the viral diseases do not have any specific antiviral drug or vaccine and therefore treatment depends on clinical conditions and symptoms. Both Covid-19 and dengue have unpredictable clinical courses and both generally require hospital monitoring for management. Most hospitals are busy managing Covid-19 and very little window is open for tackling another disease outbreak. Besides diagnostic and treatment challenges there is “limited experience” in tackling such situations and the “paucity of medical literature on management of such co-infection cases has kept everyone in dark.”

head: Corporate houses will exploit contract farming: Minister
desc: Accusing the Prime Minister of telling lies, Chhattisgarh Agriculture Minister Ravindra Choubey on Thursday said that the new farm bills passed by Parliament will help corporates to exploit corporate farming. There is no mention of the Minimum Support Price (MSP) in the bill and now corporates can open private mandis, he told the media, adding that restrictions have been lifted on the essential commodities. These are the reasons for opposing the bills, he said. Recalling the role of successive Prime Ministers in building the agriculture sector, he said India could feed its own population after subsidy was brought in to support farmers. He said that considering the state of courts now,      farmers will be unable to fight for payments legally as cases will take years to conclude. Choubey pointed out that the bills will promote black marketing and there will be no control mechanism to control the price for consumers. The BJP government will break the backbone of the country through these bills. He accused Prime Minister Narendra Modi of telling lies. Chhattisgarh farmers are already exporting tomato to Pakistan and Bangladesh and rice to Gulf countries. Last year the paddy production was 1.25 lakh tonnes which in the current Kharif season will reach 1.50 lakh tonnes. With the opening up of the market, paddy from neighbouring states of Odisha, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and others will flood Chhattisgarh. This will have a direct impact on local farmers, he said, leading to economic slavery.

head: Capt appeals to all parties in Punjab to fight unitedly against farm bills
desc: Punjab Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Thursday appealed to all political parties to rise above petty considerations and come on one platform to fight unitedly against the “treacherous” Agriculture Bills that would destroy the farmers of Punjab. Asserting his commitment to protect the rights of the farmers at all costs, the Chief Minister said that he was ready to lead the political fight against the unconstitutional anti-farmer Bills with all his might. “I will do what it takes to save my farmers and my State from these dangerous new laws, whose implementation will cripple the farming sector and also destroy Punjab’s lifeline of Agriculture,” he added. “The Congress has always stood with the farmers and will fight with them, shoulder to shoulder, to scuttle the Centre’s plans to ruin not just their own families and the labourers, who toil on the fields day and night to feed the nation, but the entire state of Punjab,” said the Chief Minister. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) led Union Government has stooped to a new low by bringing these Bills, and that too in a totally undemocratic and unparliamentary manner, said Capt Amarinder, adding that his Government, supported by the Punjab Congress, will oppose the legislations tooth and nail in the interest of not just the farmers and the State but the entire country. Lambasting the Akalis for trying to change the narrative through their concerted and deliberate efforts to transform the ‘Punjab V/s Centre’ fight into a local political clash for their vested interests, the Chief Minister said that they have changed the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) history, reducing it from a political force into the BJP’s puppet. Capt Amarinder dismissed SAD leader Harsimat Kaur Badal’s resignation from the Union Cabinet as a mockery of the Akali history of sacrifices, before the Badals hijacked the party and converted it into their personal fiefdom for their own gains. “Is giving up a berth in the Union Cabinet a sacrifice? The Badals clearly do not know the meaning of sacrifice,” he quipped, ridiculing SAD president Sukhbir Badal’s latest statement that Akali Dal can make any sacrifice for farmers. What are you still doing in the anti-farmer NDA government at the Centre, he asked the Akali leader. Sukhbir’s assertion that SAD will not let any corporate enter Punjab if the people make an Akali Dal Government in the State clearly showed that it was all about power, and the entire drama was being enacted by their party to get into the saddle, said the Chief Minister. Terming SAD’s purported U-turn on the Bills as a desperate step taken under political compulsion, when faced with the threat of total eradication from Punjab’s political arena, he pointed out that neither Sukhbir nor his wife Harsimrat even once opposed the Farm Ordinances at any point till they were presented in the Lok Sabha. “In fact, the duo continued to actively defend the Ordinances as being supportive of the farmers,” said Capt Amarinder, pointing to Sukhbir’s stand at the all-party meeting and his decision to stay away from the State Assembly session at which the resolution opposing the Bills was passed. All their claims now of being with the farmers in this fight against the Bills are a complete farce, which even the agitating farmers are taking with a pinch of salt, the Chief Minister said. MAINTAIN LAW AND ORDER, ADHERE TO COVID NORMS DURING BHARAT BANDH: CAPT APPEALS TO FARMERS Punjab Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Thursday appealed to the farmers to strictly maintain law and order, and adhere to all COVID safety protocols, during Friday’s bandh against the Agriculture Bills. “While the State Government is fully with the farmers in their fight against the Bills, and no FIRs will be registered for violation of Section 144, there should be no disturbance of the law and order during the bandh,” the Chief Minister said. He appealed to the farmers to ensure that the citizens of Punjab are not put to any inconvenience during the protest bandh, especially given the COVID crisis in the State. The Chief Minister also urged the farmers, and other organizations supporting the bandh, to maintain social distancing and wear masks at all times. The State was already in the midst of a surge in COVID-19 cases, and any violation of precautionary norms could lead to the situation spiraling out of control, he warned. He exhorted the farmers to take full care that the lives and property of the people of Punjab are not, in any way, endangered due to their agitation.

head: Don’t deny admission to students in Govt schools under any situation: Punjab Govt to schools
desc: The Punjab Government on Thursday issued instructions to the authorities not to deny admission to the students in Government schools under any situation. Notably, the enrollment in government schools has, till date, increased by 15.61 percent (3,44,986 students) and this is the highest increase in a single year till date. “Some complaints have received from the parents that their wards have been denied admission in pretext of high enrollment and lack of infrastructure,” said a spokesperson of the Punjab School Education Department. In this context the state School Education secretary Krishan Kumar directed all the District Education Officers (DEOs), secondary and elementary, of the State to give admission to the aspirants in the government schools in any case. He also directed to make appropriate arrangements at the local level in the matter of lack of infrastructure. Schools have also been asked to send proposals to start double shifts where the strength of students is very high. Earlier, the Education Department had also directed the school heads not to force the students for transfer certificates in connection with their admission in government schools and asked the school heads to admit such students at their own level. At the same time, the school principals have been directed to get a written request from the parents of the students who do not have the transfer certificate.

head: Farmers begin 3-day Rail Roko agitation in Punjab; total bandh today
desc: The farmers’ struggle against the Centre’s three agriculture bills began on Thursday with a three-day ‘Rail Roko’ campaign. Besides, the representatives of various farmers’ organizations and protestors have planned to block the roads and railway tracks at 125 places across Punjab on Friday, while making it clear that the protests would be “peaceful”. In a first of its kind development, a total of 31 farmers’ organizations of Punjab have come under one umbrella to protest against the new farm laws, announcing ‘Punjab Bandh’ on September 25. The farmers’ protest has received unprecedented response from all sections of the society, including the political parties except the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), which have announced to extend their support and participate in the bandh. “As per information from across the state, the call for bandh has received positive response from various unions of truckers, buses, tempos, employees, youngsters, students, labourers, and others,” said Darshan Pal, a representative of all farm unions. He added that as per their initial estimates, rail tracks and roads would be blocked at around 125 locations across various districts of Punjab. “We request all to block roads and rail tracks peacefully and do not respond to any call for violence as miscreants might try to create problems during bandh. The locations of bandh could be increased as per the demands of members of various organizations,” he added. As the farmers began their three-day rail roko agitation on Thursday, the Railways suspended several trains to avoid any untoward incident. The call for ‘rail roko’ was given by the Kisan Mazdoor Sangharsh Committee and later different farmers’ outfits extended their support to it. Activists of Bharatiya Kisan Union (Ekta Ugrahan) squatted on rail tracks in Barnala and Sangrur on Thursday morning. Farmers, under the banner of the Kisan Mazdoor Sangharsh Committee, have decided to squat on rail tracks near Devidaspur village in Amritsar and Basti Tanka wala in Ferozepur. The Railways official said: “14 pairs of special trains will remain suspended from September 24 till 26. The decision has been taken keeping in mind the safety of passengers and protection of railway property from any damage.” Among the trains that will remain suspended are the Golden Temple Mail (Amritsar-Mumbai Central), Jan Shatabdi Express (Haridwar-Amritsar), New Delhi-Jammu Tawi, Karambhoomi (Amritsar-New Jalpaiguri), Sachkhand Express (Nanded-Amritsar) and Shaheed Express (Amritsar-Jaynagar), officials said. Many freight and parcel trains have also been rescheduled. Kisan Mazdoor Sangharsh Committee president Satnam Singh Pannu said that they have appealed to representatives of political parties, Ministers, MPs and MLAs not to take part in the farmers’ agitation. “We are getting support from several sections, including government employees and labourers,” he added. The farmers decided to gherao BJP leaders and socially boycott those who voted in favour of the farm Bills. At the same time, the farmer leaders have appealed to the rural medical practitioners to be ready for supporting the farmers in case of medical emergencies as a large number of women are taking part in the protests. “The protest will be further intensified on September 26 as farmers will block rail tracks in Gurdaspur, Tarn Taran, Pathankot, Fazilka, Kapurthala and Jalandhar districts too,” said the committee’s state general secretary, Sarwan Singh Pandher. The Railways has decided to cancel 28 trains from Amritsar and Ferozepur stations from 6 am on Thursday in view of the safety of passengers.  The trains have been partially cancelled and short terminated till September 26 as protesters blocked rail tracks at various places, including Amritsar, Ferozepur, Sangrur, Barnala, Mansa and Nabha, said the Railways official. Among the trains that will remain suspended are the Golden Temple Mail (Amritsar-Mumbai Central), Jan Shatabdi Express (Haridwar-Amritsar), New Delhi-Jammu Tawi, Karambhoomi (Amritsar-New Jalpaiguri), Sachkhand Express (Nanded-Amritsar) and Shaheed Express (Amritsar-Jaynagar), the officials said. SUPPORT POURS IN Punjab’s 14 former IAS officers have also joined hands to appeal to the Central Government to take immediate initiative and resolve the present crisis in consultation with State Governments and representatives of other stakeholders including agitating farmers. The former babus maintained that there was no urgency to issue these ordinances when the country was fighting Corona epidemic, and added, “It seems government deliberately chose the timing so that the opposition to these measures is minimal due to fear of Corona…law or instructions issued to combat corona would be helpful in dealing with agitation against these ordinances. In spite of Government calculations, lakhs of farmers and their supporters are on the roads flouting social distancing norms. This may lead to catastrophic situation”. Maintaining that these bills impinge upon the rights of the States as well their finances, the former IAS officers said: “We have also noted with grave anguish and concern the manner in which two bills were passed in Rajya Sabha by ‘voice vote’ when several members were demanding ‘division’ (Voting). This does not augur well for our democratic functioning.” “Mere reading of the ordinances or bills would reveal that these measures would help the Corporate sector to expand in agriculture. The farmers are agitating against these bills. Most of their concerns and fears are genuine and well founded. We support their demands,” submitted a group of retired IAS officers including Dr Manmohan Singh, Dr. Harkesh Singh Sidhu, Kulbir Singh Sidhu, Gurnihal Singh Peerzada, Gurdev Singh Sidhu, Surinderjit Singh Sandhu, Sukhjit Singh Bains, Manjit Singh Narang, Prithi Chand, Capt. Narinder Singh, Tejinder Singh Dhaliwal, Sukhjit Singh Bains, Raminder Singh, Ujagar Singh. Punjab Youth Congress, which on Thursday organized statewide ‘8 Vaje 8 Minute Mashal March’ in support of the Punjab bandh call of farmers, has also decided to support the agitation. “The PYC members will perform duties during dharnas be it serving water, food or other things needed at the spot,” said PYC president Brinder Singh Dhillon. Sikhs’ mini parliament Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee (SGPC), radical Sikh organization Dal Khalsa and seminary Damdami Taksal have also extended their support to the farmers’ bandh call on September 25. Dal Khalsa spokesperson Kanwarpal Singh said, “The people of Punjab, including the political parties, should join hands for the cause. The Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) should snap its ties with the BJP to show solidarity with farmers.”

head: Punjab launches Statewide ‘Digital Parent Margdarshak Program’
desc: To build up the learning ability of anganwari-going toddlers stuck at home and guiding their parents during these unprecedented times of COVID-19 pandemic, Punjab Social Security, Women and Child Development Minister Aruna Chaudhary on Thursday formally launched ‘Digital Parent Margdarshak Program’. Chaudhary sent the first activity message to the Principal Secretary Raji P Shrivastava, who further forwarded the same to margdarshaks-Anganwadi workers to cover each and all children of the Anganwadi Centres. The Minister said that the State Govt is working tirelessly to impart education through distance learning to the students of all classes during this perilous time.“In order to help tiny-tots of anganwari centres, the mode of distance learning is being implemented in the Social Security, Women and Child Development Dept,” she said, adding that the Department, in collaboration with the Meraki Foundation, has developed the ‘Digital Parent Margdarshak Program’ as the COVID situation has brought about in-person dis-engagement resulting in more reliance on distance learning. She said that margdarshaks and functionaries of this specialized program, which will be implemented in two phases and each phase will cover 11 districts, have been given fortnight training to make this initiate a huge success. Chaudhary added that customized messages in Punjabi coupled with attractive animated videos are being sent to Anganwari workers, who forwarded these activity messages to the parents of the Anganwari-going children using various social media platforms to provide fascinating knowledgeable content to anganwari children in an amusing way.

head: Farmers Bill to go a long way in doubling income: Himachal CM
desc: The Farmers Produce Trade and Commerce (Promotion and Facilitation) Bill, 2020 passed by the Parliament is a pro farmer bill which would  not only provide better marketing facilities to the farmers to sell their produce but also go a long way in  achieving the target of Union Government to double the farmers income, Himachal Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur said on Thursday. Talking to reporters, the  Chief Minister said that APMCs and Marketing Boards would continue to function as usual and grants in aid to develop market yards will   also continue. He said that Bill would create additional trading opportunities outside the APMC market yards to help farmers in getting better prices. He said that it would also allow development of private Mandi infrastructure in the State besides improving market access for the farmers by farm gate sales/mandis. Thakur said that after getting the consent of the President, the Act would help in introduction of new technologies in the farm sector through private investment. He said that the buyers and investors who directly purchased farm produce from the farmers would not have to pay any market fee or cess. It will motivate reputed agri business companies to purchase directly from the farm fields, he added. The Chief Minister said that focus would be on electronic mode of transactions which would help in meeting the vision of Prime Minister Narendra Modi regarding ‘One Nation- One Market’.  He said that it would usher in development of cold chain infrastructure in the State as licensing would be deregulated which would ensure ease of doing business and increase investment in the agro processing sector. Accusing the Congress leaders for misleading the people of the State on the issue, he said that the Act would give price assurance of farm produce to the farmer at the time of sowing with better income options. He said that the farmers would be motivated to grow crops as per the demands of the market. Thakur said the Central Government was committed for socio-economic upliftment of the farming community and has initiated several schemes for their betterment. ATAL TUNNEL WILL STRENGTHEN SECURITY OF THE NATION, SAYS CM Ahead of the proposed visit of the Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur on Thursday presided over a meeting of officers of Kullu district in Manali. He said the construction of Atal Tunnel Rohtang will strengthen the security system of the nation paving way for throughout the year movement in this strategically important border area. He said that a traditional welcome would be accorded to the Prime Minister during his visit, directing the officers to take care of all standard operating procedures of the Covid-19 during this period and said that no negligence should be taken in this regard, at any point. The CM said social distancing should be maintained by the people even while welcoming the Prime Minister and crowding must be avoided at one place. He said that in view of Covid-19, adequate ambulances should also be maintained and necessary arrangements made for isolation.

head: A helping hand to our sanitation workers
desc: India’s rapid evolution post Independence into one of the largest economies in the world today has a lot to do with contributions from every segment of our society. In retrospect, it would perhaps not be incorrect to state that over the bygone decades, we have been successful in pushing several million Indians out of the lower layers of the existing societal strata. Yet, if there has been any inaction on our part to undertake administrative reform securing the valid interests of one particular group of people, it is our sanitation workers. Neglect and apathy towards sanitation workers, who shoulder the herculean task of keeping our towns and cities spick-and-span, has for long been the norm.  In recent years, our news channels have been flooded with the tragic stories of deaths of manual scavengers, the ones who help clean the gutters, sewer lines and the like. A national English daily reports that in 2019 alone, 110 such workers were killed due to no safety standards during their job. They have lived in marginalisation. This should prick our collective conscience because despite standing in the cusp of modernity, our society has failed them for so long. I appreciate the GARIMA scheme which has been launched under the astute leadership of Odisha Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik. Keeping the core sanitation workers and their needs in mind, the scheme shall act as a supportive pillar in their lives. This decision is certainly a pioneering effort in both its extent and magnitude. As an added plus, GARIMA shall cover not only the sanitation workers but also their families by providing them with financial support, access to healthcare facilities and administrative aid wherever necessary. The nitty-gritty has already been worked out; and by credible estimates, the plan shall initially extend immediate benefits to around one lakh people. On the administrative side, Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF), retirement benefits and post-retirement pensions have been prioritised for these workers and their families. An initial corpus of ?50 crore has also been sanctioned by the State Government, which will help the cause further. Of course, this is the beginning. In the future, I am certain that the scheme shall be extended to cover all sanitation workers in the State who may at present have been left out of its ambit. My idea is that it is crucial to begin with whatever is at hand.  While the wrongs of the past cannot be wholly undone, it is upon our hands to effect whatever changes we possibly can because future is in our hands. I am hopeful and confident that GARIMA shall bring about a definitive transformation in the lives of our sanitation workers. (Dr Samanta is MP, Kandhamal, and founder, KIIT & KISS)

head: InBrief
desc: Man found dead in B’pur temple premises Brahmapur: The body of an unidentified man was recovered from the premises of a temple near Mentu Chhak under the Bada Bazar police station in Brahmapur town on Thursday. The deceased was found lying in a pool of blood with two bricks lying near the body. It is suspected that he was bludgeoned to death. The person’s identity was yet to be established, till last reports came in. Police have sent the body for postmortem and started an investigation to ascertain the motive behind the crime. 130 kg ganja seized; 2 held in Gajapati Paralakhemundi: Police have launched a massive crackdown against the ganja smugglers in Gajapati district on the instructions of Superintendent of Police Tapan Kumar Patnaik. In a raid on the residence of a person of Gamusahi of Anuguru panchayat under the R Udaygiri police station, police seized 130 kg of the contraband and arrested two persons in this connection. The accused were identified as Samson Majhi and his associate Alio Majhi. Later, the seized ganja was weighed in the presence of Nuagad Assistant Tehsildar AK Pradhan. A case was lodged at the R Udaygiri police station. Hyena found dead near Balangir railway track Balangir: Much to the dismay of animal lovers, a hyena was found dead near railway tracks at Karuanjhar village under the Lathore forest range in Balangir district this morning. The nocturnal animal is believed to have been died after being hit by a train. The exact cause of death would be known after autopsy, said a forest official. “Earlier, we had informed railway authorities about the movement of wild animals in this railway section,” said Lathore Forest Range Officer Prabhati Seth. Ideal teacher of Bhapur passes away Bhapur (Nayagarh):  Panchanan Sethi, an ideal teacher of Nandabar village under  Bhapur block’s Karabar grama panchayat ub Batagarg district, died due to cardiac arrest on Wednesday. He was 69. Many noted persons of the area visited Sethi’s house and paid last respect to him. His body was cremated at village graveyard. His eldest son Biranchi Nayaran lit funeral pyre. Bhapur block Vice-Chairman Gayadhar Parida mourned his death. Rs  2L looted in front of bank in K’jhar KEONJHAR: Unidentified miscreants looted more than Rs 2 lakh from a person in front of the DCB Bank in Keonjhar town on Thursday.Jajati Behera, a trader, had come to the bank in a car with his brother for depositing money. He was carrying a bag containing Rs 10 lakh. Jajati took out Rs 7.7 lakh from the bag and went inside the bank leaving Rs 2.3 lakh in the possession of his brother.Moments later, three bike-borne miscreants stopped near the vehicle and had a conversation with Jajati’s brother. Soon later, one of the looters picked up the bag containing the cash from the car and the trio fled the spot. A complaint in this regard was lodged with the Keonjhar town police and efforts were on by cops to trace and nab the robbers.

head: CBI arrests MES JE for taking bribe
desc: The CBI has arrested a Junior Engineer (JE) of the Military Engineer Services (MES) here for allegedly demanding and accepting a bribe of Rs 30,000 from a contractor. The accused Rajiv Ranjan had reportedly demanded the bribe from Pabitra Mohan Parida, a private contractor with MES in Paradip, for forwarding resumes of six employees of his firm to the office of GE(I), MES, Bhubaneswar for formal approval relating to the work order. Parida lodged a complaint with anti-graft agency authorities, following which a trap was laid by CBI sleuths and the JE was caught red-handed at his office while accepting bribe fromcomplainant.

head: ‘Include B’ngir, Subarnapur in Swadesh Darshan’
desc: Balangir MP Sangeeta Singh Deo has urged the Union Tourism Minister to include Subarnapur and Balangir as heritage, spiritual and rural circuits in the Swadesh Darshan scheme. Raising the matter during the Zero Hour in Lok Sabha on Wednesday, Singh Deo pointed out that Sonepur, located near the confluence point of the Tel and the Mahanadis, has several ancient temples of historical, architectural and religious importance, established between 8th and 13th Century. Baidyanath Temple, Sureshwari Temple, Kapileshwar Temple, Godhenesswar temple, Papakshya Ghat, Patalisrikeshtra are some of the historical shrines. The Samadhi peetha of famous saint poet Bhima Bhoi, whose poems have been inscribed in the Parliament and in the UNO premises, and pre-historical cave in Puja Dunguri and Aareto are also located in the district. Two heritage sites, Harishankar and ChousathiYogini Temples, in Balangir district need to be preserved and developed to help boost the economy of district, said Singh Deo.

head: ‘Set up textile park for Ganjam migrant returnees’
desc: Activist and lawyer Srikanta Padhi has submitted a memorandum addressed to the State Governor through the RDC (Southern Division) on a five-point charter of demands on the miseries of Ganjam migrant returnees. Even though Ganjam is the most populous district in the State with all natural resources but its place in earning and employment map of the country is quire precarious, he pointed out.In view of the country-wide Covid-19 pandemic, more than 4 lakh Ganjam migrants have returned back to their native places in  Ganjam and are in great fiscal stress. They are passing through mental trauma since last seven months, he added. The key demands raised in the memorandum include establishment of a textile park at national heritage village Padmanabhapur in Ganjam district and engagement of more than 3 lakh skilled and non-skilled migrant workers; registration for workers from Ganjam migrating to other States and a data base; halting of all trains passing through Brahampur Railway station; development of neglected Odia migrant workers in Surat and posting of a senior IAS officer of the State to look after the issue; revival of the Aska Cotton Mill and establishment of another cotton mill at Hinjilikatu to generate employment for the locals.

head: Odisha still denies SC/ST/OBC status to Dalit Muslims
desc: In recent times, the citizenship of the Muslims has been a hot topic for discussion, while many more important socio-economic issues concerning them are swept under the carpet.The issues of participation in employment, business, education, health and  access to basic amenities ,ownership over land and most importantly, participation in governance of the Muslims are ignored inspite of two major landmark commission reports on Indian minority in post independent India.  The first commission was headed by Justice Rajindara Sachar (2006), former Chief Justice of Delhi High Court and the second was headed by Justice Ranganath Mishra, former Chief Justice of India (2007). Both the reports are an eye-opener to public about the status of religious minorities in India. Among the religious minorities, the situation of Dalit Muslims is worst as they are prosecuted because of their caste based social identities. They continue to suffer inspite of change in their faith while they are almost disconnected from their social groups by legally losing status of Scheduled Caste. The SC status is not legally religion neutral and has been restricted to Hindu, Sikh (1955) and Buddhists (1990) only till date. The Dalit Muslims are also socially alienated from the major Dalit population of India commonly identified as Scheduled Caste. After OBC reservation, many of Dalit Muslims are included in OBC category in different States. Islam is the second largest religion of India. Studies by many such as ISI, New Delhi (2010), Abdur Rahman, Denial and Deprivation, (2019),Dalits in the Muslim and Christian communities ,National Commission for Minorities, repot by Satish Deshpande and Geetika Bapna, Department of Sociology ,University of Delhi (2008),  and the various commission reports found that the Muslim society in India is not homogeneous as they are divided into four major social and economic classes under the  influence of caste system in India.In Indian society the Ashraf, (Sayyads, Sheikhs, Mughals, Pathans) are the land owners, civil and religious leaders.   Ajlafs (mostly similar to Hindu Sudras/OBC) are mostly artisans and occupational groups such as barbar, tailor, weaver etc.   The Arzals are the lowest like their Hindu counterparts. The Arzals are the Dalits of the Muslim community. They constitute a separate most deprived group within the Muslim society. Similarly the untouchables/scheduled castes converted to Christianity are called as Dalit Christians.The change in religion has not contributed much to upgrade their social and economic status in the new religion and even within their own religious fraternity; rather they continue to face the same discriminatory treatment in social life and majority of them are engaged in age old unclean occupations such as scavenging, washing, cleaning etc. These issues are swept under the carpet. Landlessness is very high among these communities. They are deprived of basic amenities such as  homestead land , good housing , drinking water , toilet , electricity and sanitary facilities in their hamlets/Muhallas which are segregated in case of Dalit  Muslims. Usually the Government schemes very seldom reach to these hamlets because of their locations and discriminatory attitude of the governing elites. The condition of elders, women and children in family is very miserable. They cannot enter into any petty business but they are only selectively allowed to do few jobs since generations together. Very less has been done for their schooling and economic development and also for socialization and secularization. Inter caste /jamaats marriage is rare and often leads to social tension because of social hierarchy among Muslims. The suffering of Dalit Muslims is not addressed properly. The Kaka Kalelkara Commission of 1955 and Mandal Commission of 1980 have very well recognized the issues of social and educational backwardness among major Muslim groups /castes and recommended to include them in OBCs. The implementation of OBC reservation though is late but placed Muslims  as socially and educationally backward classes and also entitled them to avail reservation in education and jobs. The States such as Kerala ,Tamilanadu, AP ,Telengana and Karnataka, Manipur, Bihar, West Bengal and Uttar Pradesh have made specific percentage of reservation for Muslims as backward class and most backward class. But in Odisha there is no minority commission and backward caste Muslims are not identified either as OBC or SEBC whereas Dalit Christians are included in the SCBC list in the State. Reservation in education and employment is necessary  to revamp the social and economic status of the downtrodden. It has certainly contributed to change hereditary  caste based occupations. Modern Education exposes to rational thinking, global outlook and aims at building a world where every individual lives with dignity and self-respect which Jyoti Rao Phule, Dr Ambedkar and  Sir Syed Ahamad Khan, Hamid Dalwai  always advocated for.  In Odisha minorities constitute 6 per cent of the total population of the State where Muslims with 10 lakh population account for 2.5 pet cent of the population. However, thr Muslim communities have been neglected much with denial of OBC or SEBC status.  The State Government has not set up any minority commission to look after the issues of minorities including Muslim minorities. There is no dedicated minority department with Minister from minority groups hrading it. Also there is absence of any minority financial corporation to encourage self-employment among minority youths. There is no allocation for upgrading of Madrasas for quality education of Muslim children and promotion of Urdu language. But almost all parties have minority cells to satisfy the minority political leaders as party agents. (manasbbsr15@gmail.com)

head: Rs  283-cr damage to embankments due to floods
desc: The total damages caused to river embankments and canals due to last month’s floods have been estimated to be over Rs 283 crore, said Water Resources Engineer-in-Chief (EIC) Jyotirmaya Rath on Thursday. In a letter to Principal Secretary of  concerned department, EIC said that after recession of floodwater, a final report of damages in embankments and canals under major and medium sector has been prepared and damages were estimated at Rs 283.74 crore.

head: NHRC notices Centre, State over students’ plight
desc: The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) on Wednesday issued a notice to the Secretary, Education Department, and the Secretary, Ministry of HRD, asking them to submit action taken reports (ATR) in connection with the hardships and miseries being faced by financially poor students living in remote and inaccessible areas in getting education online due to lack of internet.The NHRC issued the notices on a petition filed by human rights activist and lawyer Radhakanta Tripathy.In his petition, Tripathy mentioned that 38 lakh students in Odisha are deprived of teaching due to non-availability of mobile network in their areas. Students are walking kilometers, climbing water tanks, trees and hills for getting internet connection required for online education during covid-19 pandemic in remote and inaccessible areas, he mentioned, adding that the State Government has also admitted it.He said more than one crore students across India have been deprived of education due to lack of active Government intervention. He requested the NHRC to ensure smart mobile phones to each one of financially poor students and to ensure proper electricity supply and network connectivity for online classes at home during exigencies and digital connectivity throughout the year in the entire country.

head: Accused cop under probe purview: CP
