desc: The policeman accused in the minor girl gang-rape case in Bhubaneswar is also under the purview of investigation, said Twin City Commissioner of Police (CP) Sudhanshu Sarangi on Thursday. He told reporters that a proper investigation of the incident is underway and action would be taken once the truth and evidence come out. However, he refused to divulge further details saying that it is too early to comment on the matter. “Any kind of statement now will hamper the investigation process. We will inform the court and concerned authorities about the findings of the probe when the time comes,” Sarangi added. Earlier on September 21, OTV managing director Jagi Mangat Panda had reappeared before the Odisha State Commission for Women responding to the notice served by the panel in connection with the incident. However, she could not stay for the hearing and left citing a prior engagement. Commission Chairperson Minati Behera has said a fresh notice has been issued to Panda for her appearance through the DCP.Notably, as per a complaint lodged by the rape victim’s mother with Odisha State Commission for Protection of Child Rights (OSCPCR), her daughter was raped by several employees of the TV channel and a policeman for around 15 days during April and May. The accused committed the crime after tying the hands and legs of the girl. They also recorded videos of the incident and threatened the victim to leak it. It may be mentioned that the girl’s mother was then working as a receptionist at the OTV. The woman has further alleged that the accused had threatened her daughter to kill her and her mother if she disclosed their names. The woman has mentioned in her complaint that though she reported the matter to the OTV MD, the latter did not take any action against the accused and suppressed the incident. The MD also pressurised her not to proceed further in the case, she has further alleged.

head: Govt to put up posters  of sexual offenders
desc: Expressing displeasure over the increasing incidents of crime against women in the state, Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath on Thursday directed officials to take strict action against those involved in sexual harassment cases.  The chief minister also ordered officials that posters those harassing females be put up at public places to “name and shame” them. Earlier, posters were put up by the administration to “name and shame” the accused who allegedly caused damage to public property during the protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) in the state capital.  According to an official communiqué, women police personnel have been tasked with the responsibility of implementing ‘Mission Durachari’. They will identify offenders, whose posters will then be put up at public places across the state.  The release said that the operation would be implemented as to the anti-Romeo squads operated in the state. The police teams in every district would be crack the whip on criminals committing crimes against women. The chief minister further said that people should know who were the people who were vitiating the atmosphere in society and indulging in crime against women.  He said that in case any incident related to crime against women took place, the beat in-charge, chowki in-charge, station officer and the circle officer would be held responsible. Meanwhile, ‘Operation Shakti’ was also launched in Lucknow to tackle crimes against women in the state.  On the instructions of IG Lucknow Range, Laxmi Singh, this operation was conducted in Unnao, Hardoi, Sitapur, Lakhimpur, Rae Bareli and Lucknow rural area.  So far, action has been initiated against 2,200 accused in a month. FIRs have been registered against 822 people while 770 accused have been served notice. The action also includes litigation, restriction and imposition of challans for hampering the peace. This action was taken after reports of molestation surfaced from the area.

head: BJP leader alleges sexual harassment
desc: After Bharatiya Janata Party MLA in Aligarh created trouble for the party by threatening the local district police chief not to harass the party leaders in the beginning of this week, now a former office-bearer of BJP District Minority Cell in Aligarh alleged sexual harassment and attempt on life by a senior leader of her own party.  She too accused the local police of working under the influence of the BJP leader and claimed that instead of lodging an FIR, she made a complaint to senior party leaders, including the chief minister, requesting them to punish the guilty leader.  Farheen Mohisin, hailing from Usmanphada area of Delhigate in Aligarh, levelled sexual harassment charges against Imran Aleem Saifi, district president of the party’s minority cell in Aligarh.  She claimed that after she opposed his sexual advances and issued a warning, the leader sent his goons to her house and they attacked her and her husband last Monday. The entire incident was recorded on close circuit television.  Mohisin said that finding no other way and seeing that Imran was adamant to “outrage her modesty”, she had quit the party post. She was secretary in the district minority cell.  She denied lodging an FIR and said that she knew that some leaders were trying to bring a bad name to the party in Aligarh so she appraised the party top leadership of the issue and hoped that she would get justice.  Sources said that Imran denied all charges and claimed that efforts were made to malign his image.    Meanwhile, hitting out at the Yogi Adityanath government over its decision to put up posters of people accused of eve teasing, the Samajwadi Party on Thursday asked the government to put up posters of those supporting rape accused Kuldeep Singh Sengar and Swami Chinmayanand. SP leader Sunil Singh Sajan said here on Thursday  that the administration had failed to curb crimes against women and its ‘anti-Romeo Squads’ constituted for women safety had failed. “Today, the Yogi Adityanath government issued a new diktat of putting up posters of eve-teasers. It should first say how many laws has it come up with in this regard so far. The government also said that those taking sides of the culprits will be punished. So will posters of those taking sides of rape accused like Kuldeep Singh Sengar and Chinmayanand will also be out up?,” the SP MLC asked. “We too believe that stringent action must be taken against the culprits, but let the courts do their work,” he said.

head: CM directive to link medical  institutes with virtual ICUs
desc: Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath has asked officials to start the process to link medical institutes with virtual ICUs by using technology in such a way that the serious patients may get treatment from experienced doctors. He also asked the officials to keep ventilators/high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) functional in all districts. Presiding over a high-level Unlock review meeting at the Lok Bhawan here on Thursday, Yogi also directed officials to adopt an effective strategy to control spread of novel coronavirus in districts where 100 or more positive cases are being found every day for the last one week. The chief minister directed the chief secretary, additional chief secretaries of home (health and medical education) along with medical experts to hold a detailed discussion to finalise the action plan in this regard. He reiterated that nodal officers be nominated in these districts with deployment of special secretary-rank officers with each of nodal officer. The chief minister asked officials to maximise contact tracing for effective control on coronavirus infection. He also asked them to target high risk groups and put them to tests.  He said one-third of the total Covid tests per day should be conducted through RT-PCR and the rest by rapid antigen method.  He further directed officials to increase the number of beds in Covid Level-2 and Level-3 hospitals. The chief minister stressed on taking up enforcement exercise to check observance of social distancing and use of masks by people. “Create micro-containment zones as and where required. Public address systems should be functional all the time to spread awareness about protection from coronavirus and the prevailing traffic rules,” he said. The chief minister directed officials to maintain the availability of all protective gears, including masks, PPE kits and sanitiser and medicines, testing kits used in the treatment.  “The Health department should also review these requirements from time to time,” he added, stressing on sanitation and cleanliness. The chief minister said that the people should be sensitised about protection from COVID-19 in view of coming festivals. He said the festivals had to be celebrated at home and no public functions should be organised and all the norms of social distancing and use of masks should be followed strictly. The chief minister directed officials to review progress of Smart City projects and AMRUT Yojana on a regular basis. He asked them to proceed in an organised manner to get maximum benefits of the special economic package announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. He said that more and more labourers and street vendors should be facilitated to get loans and the loaning for MSME units through packages should be facilitated accordingly.  He asked the officials to keep cow shelters in Bundelkhand region properly functional.

head: CM: Uniformity in education  to bring equality in society Dedicates to the people U-Rise portal
desc: Stressing the need of imparting uniform education to all the students of the state, Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath on Thursday said that uniformity in education would bring equality in society.    “In view of the future requirements, the education should be unified and all levels of education should be coordinated so that students have alternatives to choose their areas of skill,’’ the chief minister said while dedicating to the people of the state the Unified Re-imagined Innovation for Student Empowerment (U-Rise) portal at a function in Lok Bhawan here on Thursday. It is a joint initiative of the Technical Education department, Training and Employment department and Skill Development Mission that has been developed by Dr APJ Abdul Kalam Technical University.    Underlining the importance of this portal, the chief minister said the convergence of educationists, employers and researchers through this portal would benefit lakhs of students.  “It will empower them by providing them every possible information from online exams to digital contents, digital assessment, to digital examination papers, webinar to internship, e-library, recorded video content and lastly employment,” he pointed out. The chief minister said that about 20 lakh students, who were getting vocational and technical education, would be benefited from this portal which would guide them from learning to career counselling to employment. The e-content, e-library and online courses available on this portal would reach even the most interior parts of the state, he said.     The chief minister said the National Education Policy-2020 also espouses the cause of uniform education.  “There is ample scope and need of the time for a multi-discipline education system weaving various streams like science, arts, social science, humanities, engineering and sports into a unified syllabus,” he said. The chief minister said digital technology brought by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the country in 2014 had proved to be very useful.  “We managed to bust several conspiracies of fake teachers through digital technology,” he said. Through this, all students, teachers, trainers, institutions providing employment related to technical education, ITI and skill development may converge on one place with all the relevant information about the life-cycle of a student being available here.  It will not only empower the students but also provide them a useful platform to get exposed and open up to the entire world. The aim of the portal is to ensure uniform quality education to all the students who can improve their learning curve while using this portal.    It, in fact, is a place with a unique network of trainers, faculty and industry. The students once registered will continue to receive its benefits life-long and their track records will also be digitally stored which will help them in the future for employment purposes etc.   On the occasion, the chief minister released Rs 100 crore in the second phase of Deendayal Upadhyay Quality Improvement programme. It will be spent on the development of digital and physical infrastructure of various technical institutions in the state.

head: Covid recovery rate  increases to 82 pc
desc: After consistently touching the over 5,000-mark for the last more than a month, Friday brought good news for Uttar Pradesh as the number of COVID-19 cases declined, bringing relief among the officials as the recovery rate climbed to 82 per cent. Additional Chief Secretary (Health) Amit Mohan Prasad said 4,674 fresh coronavirus positive cases were reported on Thursday while 4,922 people were discharged, taking the recovery rate to 82.19 per cent. Now the tally of confirmed coronavirus cases in the state has gone up to 3,84,277. “There are 61,300 active cases in the state while 3,17,611 COVID-19 patients have recovered, including 4,922 people discharged from hospitals on Thursday,” Prasad said. On Wednesday, 1,53,458 Covid sample were tested in the state. “There are 31,751 asymptomatic patients in home isolation and 3,644 patients in private hospitals and 185 in the semi-paid hotels while the rest are in government-run Covid hospitals,? he said. The additional chief secretary said that over 3.78 surveillance teams covered 1,18,865 areas in the state and visited 2.48 crore houses and checked the health of over 12.32 crore people. Meanwhile, Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath has directed officials to pay attention in 16 Covid-prone districts where the daily increase of the patients is over 100. He has asked officials to deploy a special team to monitor the arrangements and to strengthen contact tracing in districts like Lucknow, Kanpur Nagar, Gorakhpur, Prayagraj, Noida, Meerut, Ghaziabad, Moradabad, Jhansi Saharanpur and Varanasi.  He also asked the hospitals to link with virtual ICUs so that the critical patients could get more benefit. He said the high risk people should be tested immediately.

head: Bizarre case of teachers'  exploitation in Meerut
desc: In a bizarre incident of exploitation through blackmailing in Meerut, as many as 52 teachers of a private school have collectively lodged a complaint with the local police allging that the school management was covertly filming them in the school’s washrooms and then using the videos and photographs to blackmail them into working without salary for several months. Sources said that the teachers, in their complaint, stated that the secretary of the school’s management committee threatened them with their objectionable photographs and videos whenever they asked for the payment of their pending salaries.  Based on the complaint, the police, on Wednesday, registered an FIR against the secretary and his son under sections 504 (intentional insult), 354 (a) (sexual harassment) and 354 (c) (voyeurism) of the Indian Penal Code. Meanwhile, the secretary dismissed the allegations of sexual harassment leveled against him.  “There is no CCTV inside the women’s toilet. But they have been installed in the gents’ toilets. This was done against the backdrop of recent cases of murder inside some schools,” the secretary told some media persons.  The secretary, however, admitted that for the past few months, the school had failed to pay salaries to the teachers. He attributed this failure to the ongoing pandemic situation. A case has been registered and investigation is underway, Station House Officer (SHO) of the Sadar Bazaar police station, Vijay Gupta said, adding that a team of officials from the forensic department has been roped in to provide assistance to the police in the investigation.  He said that the entire Close Circuit Television footage would be examined and the statements of the staff and even students would be recorded before initiating any action.  The financial record of the school will be also scrutinised to confirm whether the salaries were not paid due to money shortage or not.  It may be mentioned that in 2017, the same school had ordered its students to get their hair cut like chief minister Yogi Adityanath. The students were also asked to not keep beards as the school was “not a madarasa where people offer namaz”.

head: Power tariff hiked in State from Oct 1
desc: Electricity consumers in State would have to pay more towards their power bills from October 1 as Odisha Electricity Regulatory Commission (OERC) on Wednesday approved a hike in energy tariff by 20 paise per unit for retail users. However, revised rates would not be applicable to Kutir Jyoti (BPL) and agricultural consumers. While approving average cost of supply as 524.62 paise for  FY 2020-21,  OERC has fixed 270 paise per unit up to 50 units, 450 paise/unit for consumption above 50 units and up to 200 units, 550 paise/unit for the consumption above 200 units and up to 400 units and 590 paise/unit for consumption above 400 units for domestic category. There is no change in meter rent, monthly minimum fixed charge (MMFC) and demand charge. The OERC said a 2%-rebate over and above normal rebate would be allowed on bill to low-transmission domestic and single-phase general purpose category of consumers only over and above all rebated who pay through digital means.

head: BRIEF
desc: Srikanth takes charge of Bhopal circle Bhopal: KJ Srikanth, General Manager has taken over charge of Bhopal Circle. He has vast experience of over 35 years in various fields of Banking. He joined erstwhile Syndicate Bank in the year 1986 and rose to the level of General Manager. Prior to his joining as Circle Head of Bhopal Circle he was serving as CEO at London branch of erstwhile Syndicate Bank. He had served in different capacities at various branches and administrative units including credit, treasury, retail etc. He is committed to provide best customer service by implementing  the guidelines of the Government as well as Bank.Canara Bank which is 4th Largest Public Sector Banks in India is having more than 459 branches in Bhopal Zone, covering entire Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh States.   IGRMS to hold lecture on Mahatma Gandhi Bhopal: Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sangrahalaya is organising a Museum popular lecture to commemorate of Marking 150th birth anniversary of Mahatama Gandhi, on Friday.  Prof. Vinay Kumar Shrivastava Director of Anthropology of India, Kolkata will speak on ‘The Mahatma and Tribes of India’. The lecture will be organized through Facebook, YouTube online mediums from 6.00 PM.

head: CM Chouhan directs to fill vacant posts in Govt Depts
desc: Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has directed to begin the process of filling vacant posts in the departments of Home, Revenue, Public Works, Jail, Education and other departments immediately. Recruitment is estimated for about 25,000 posts including about 15 thousand teachers and 10 thousand posts in other departments. In a meeting held at the CM House, Chief Minister Chouhan said that the process of filling the vacant posts in the departments should be completed to ensure smooth conduct of public welfare works. Action should be taken at the Professional Examination Board, Public Service Commission and departmental level in this regard. Chief Minister Chouhan reviewed the recruitment of posts at the departmental level and instructed to adopt the entire process in a holistic way. Chouhan said that the recruitment process should be completed keeping in mind the essential rules and procedures relating to filling of the vacant posts. According to an estimate, PEB will conduct examinations in the coming months for about 10 thousand posts. These include 3272 posts of Police Constable under Home Department, 863 posts of Rural Agriculture Extension Officer and Senior Agriculture Development Officer in Farmers Welfare and Agriculture Development Department, 493 posts of Constable Radio Cadre in Home Department, 372 posts of Revenue Inspector, 302 posts of ITI Training Officer in Directorate of Skill Development. Apart from this, posts like Shorthand writer Assistant Grade-3, Steno Typist, Stenographer, Data Entry Operator, Statistics Officer and Peon, Chowkidar, Ward boy, Cleaner, Watermen and Cooks will be recruited in various departments. It was informed in the meeting that Primary School Teacher Eligibility Test is proposed in December 2020. Currently, preparations are also being made to conduct various examinations of Directorate of Technical Education, Department of Animal Husbandry and Department of Agriculture by PEB. These exams are proposed in October and November 2020 according to academic session. A large number of applications have been received for these posts. As many as 6.57 lakh applications have been received this year for teachers only. Chief Secretary Iqbal Singh Bains, Agriculture Production Commissioner  K.K. Singh, Principal Secretary to Chief Minister Manish Rastogi, Commissioner Public Relations Sudam Khade and other officials were present in the meeting.

head: Rain recorded across State, Bhopal receives heavy spell
desc: Intermittent rainfall has been witnessed in the State. State capital has recorded heavy spells in the past 24 hours and more rainfall is likely to be witnessed in the next 2-3 days. The monsoon activities are strong across the State and pattern would prevail said Met official. The State capital witnessed rainfall during the night on Tuesday and which prevailed in the day with intermittent heavy spells during the day. Rainfall continued till late in the evening and night. Power disruptions in the night and during day in Wednesday was witnessed with water logging at several places. State capital recorded 4 cm of rainfall till 5.30 in the evening on Wednesday while the spell continued in the region in the night. Jabalpur recorded 3.2 cm of rainfall,Ujjain recorded 2 cm, Indore recorded 3 cm,  Damoh and Satna recorded 2cm, Shajapur and Guna recorded 5 cm of rainfall in the day on Wednesday. Several regions would witness heavy rainfall as Met department issued warning of heavy rainfall in Sagar division, Vidisha, Raisen, Hoshangabad, Betul, Khargone, Barwani, Alirajpur, Jhabua, Dhar, Indore, Ratlam, Ujjain, Ashok Nagar, Shivpuri, Datia, Rewa, Satna, Umaria, Katni and Jabalpur districts. Among regions which would receive rainfall and likely to witness thundery activities and thunder lightening are Rewa, Sagar, Indore, Ujjain, Hoshangabad, Bhopal, Gwalior and Chambal divisions.  The rainfall pattern would be witnessed for the next 6-7 days and as the system movement, the regions would receive changes accordingly. The rainfall activities are likely to decrease by September 30.

head: Married man arrested for firing outside ex-girlfriend's home for ignoring him: Delhi Police
desc: The Delhi Police has nabbed a 27-year-old man for allegedly opening fire outside the residence of his former girlfriend in southeast Delhi as she had been ignoring him after his marriage. The accused has been identified as Sumit Tomar. According to R P Meena, the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), Southeast district, late on Sunday night Tomar opened fire in Dharampal Colony in Aali Vihar when the 24-year-old woman was at home with her family. “After hearing the gunshot, she opened the door and found Tomar with a country-made gun in his hand. On seeing her, he shouted, ‘come outside, I will kill you and your family’. Then he ran away,” said the DCP. “She found the main gate damaged and an empty cartridge and bullet lead. The woman told police that she was in a relationship with Tomar for 10 years but after his marriage in 2018, she had started ignoring him,” said the DCP. “Tomar did not like it and had threatened her with dire consequences. During investigation, police received information on Tuesday that Tomar was hiding in Aali Vihar jungle. A raid was conducted and Tomar was arrested,” said the DCP. “During interrogation, Tomar told police that he wanted to marry the woman but could not. He had procured the gun last month from Agra,” said the DCP adding the gun was found with him.

head: MP Govt revives Sambal Yojana, gives Rs 80 cr to 3,700 beneficiaries
desc: Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan has said that Madhya Pradesh Government considers welfare of the poor as paramount. A practical scheme like Sambal which supports the needy and poor through equitable distribution of resources, was discontinued by the former Government. The implementation of the Sambal Yojana, which provides financial assistance from the period before birth to conditions of to untimely death, will now continue. Chief Minister Chouhan transferred ex-gratia amount of Rs 80 crore to the account of 3700 beneficiaries of Sambal Yojana in a programme organized at Minto Hall Bhopal on Wednesday. PERMANENT HOUSE FOR ALL IN THREE YEARS   Chief Minister Shri Chouhan said that Sambal is a scheme of equitable distribution of resources. This scheme has become a great support for the poor. Chouhan said that the former government had also snatched the morsel from the mouth. Pregnant women were denied laddoos which were to provide them nutrition. The plan was discontinued at the behest of the former government.

head: Railways to go for PPP model to improve services
desc: In order to introduce modern technologies and improve efficiencies, Indian Railways is planning to use ‘Public Private Partnership’ (PPP) model to complete some of the initiatives to improve services. “It is estimated that Indian Railways would need Capital investment of around Rs 50 lakh crore up to 2030 for network expansion and capacity augmentation, rolling stock induction and other modernization works to enable better delivery of passenger and freight services and to improve its modal share in transport,” said Minister of Railways and Commerce and Industry Piyush Goyal in a written reply to a question in Rajya Sabha on Wednesday. “One of the PPP initiatives is to invite partners to invest and induct modern rakes over select routes to provide world class services to the passengers. As part of this initiative, the Ministry of Railways has invited applications for investment and induction of modern rakes over select routes through Public Private Partnership (PPP) to provide world class services to the passengers,” he said. Accordingly, the MOR has issued 12 ‘Requests for Qualification’ (RFQs) on 1st July, 2020 for operation of passenger trains over approximately 109 origin-destination pairs (divided into 12 clusters) through PPP on ‘Design, Build, Finance and Operate’ (DBFO) basis, he said, adding that the routes are spread across various states covering the entire railway network straddling across the boundaries of the States. The minister further said that the railways had conducted a survey through ‘Interactive Voice Response System’ (IVRS) on passenger amenities including train and station cleanliness. “One lakh calls were made every day to reserved passengers randomly for obtaining their feedback. The feedback has been discontinued since the Covid outbreak as a very limited number of trains has been plying. However, no survey is being conducted based on the socio-economic profile of passengers,” he said. Replying to another question, he said that in order to cater to the travelling needs of lower income groups, Indian Railways operate mail express trains having general class coaches and sleeper class coaches. “Besides this, fully unreserved services like Jan Sadharan, Janseva, Jan Nayak Express, Antyodaya Express, some Intercity trains, passenger trains are also operated by Indian Railways. Further, trains are also augmented with general Class and sleeper class coaches as per commercial viability and operational feasibility,” he said. Accordingly, during the years 2019-20, of the total 1490 coaches utilized for augmentation of existing services, 940 coaches (524 sleeper class, 389 general class and 27 second class chair car coaches) were to facilitate the passengers of lower income groups, he said. Augmentation of services and coaches are an ongoing activity based on various parameters including demand, commercial and operational viability. “The work of redevelopment is in advanced stage at Gandhinagar (Western Railway) and Habibganj (West Central Railway) railway stations.  Re-development works are in progress at Gomtinagar (North Eastern Railway) and Ayodhya stations (Northern Railway). Contracts have been awarded for redevelopment of Anand Vihar (Northern Railway), Bijwasan (Northern Railway) and Chandigarh (Northern Railway) railway stations,” he informed.

head: Sarla Birla Varsity celebrates 3rd Foundation Day
desc: Third Foundation Day was organized by Sarla Birla University, Ranchi, Jharkhand on Wednesday, in which BK Dalan, Pro -Chancellor of the University as the Chief Guest, Treasurer of Bharat Arogya and Gyan Mandir Trust Mr. Dau Lal Binani, Sarla Binani, Chief Executive Officer of the University cum in-charge Vice-Chancellor Dr. Pradip Kumar Varma, Registrar Dr. Vijay Kumar Singh etc. jointly lit the work by lighting the lamp.  Pro-Chancellor Bijay Kumar Dalan while highlighting the objectives of the establishment of the University said that the Birla Group always focuses on quality education.  To provide quality and research-based education is the main motto of our university. The treasurer of Bharat Arogya and Gyan Mandir, Dau Lal Binani said that the work done by the university in such a short time is commendable and praiseworthy. The CEO cum in-charge Vice Chancellor Dr. Pradeep Kumar Verma while congratulating people on the Foundation Day said that today is a day of celebration for the university. He said that the aim of the university is to make the citizen radically qualified for a contemplative nation. Prof. (Dr.) Vijay Kumar Singh, Registrar, SBU presented the Annual report 2019-20, wishing all officers, officials and employees on the foundation day and said that as per the syllabus new trends here, in the direction of preparing the citizens of the global mental level to achieve their goal. On this occasion, Dean ID & CS Prof. Sanjeev Bajaj, Dean Engineering Prof. Sridhar B. Dandin, Dr. Radha Madhav Jha, Dean of Humanities and Subani Bara, Principal of Nursing, also expressed their views. On this occasion, the book of the Faculty Development Program conducted by the University was also released by all the guests. The program was conducted by Dr. Ria Mukherjee while the vote of thanks was accompanied by Prof. Rahul Vats, DSW of the University. Finally the program ended with the national anthem.

head: Vedanta-Electrosteel aims to completely shift to Electrical Vehicles by 2025
desc: Vedanta Electrosteel (ESL) is planning to convert its 35 small cars into Electrical Vehicles (EVs) by 2023. The company also plans to take up the conversion of buses in the next phase and aims to completely shift to EVs by 2025, informed Public Relation Official ESL. Jharkhand has adopted an e-mobility program in partnership with the Energy Efficiency Services Limited (EESL). The Jharkhand Bijli Vitran Nigam Limited (JBVNL) has signed an agreement with EESL for the deployment of 50 electric vehicles (EVs) at various JBVNL offices in Ranchi. In line with the mission of India and Jharkhand e-mobility program, ESL is planning to switch to electric vehicles in place of conventional vehicles run on petrol and diesel by 2025, said the official. The switching to Electric vehicles will help in Reduction in GHG emissions: The fuel efficiency is much more in EVs as compared to the conventional mode of transportation run by petrol and diesel. This initiative would reduce the scope of -3 emission of the industry; Reduction in Noise Pollution: EVs are generally quite silent and hence will produce less or no noise; Safe in nature: The chances of an explosion are very less as there is no use of inflammable substances in it. Moreover, because of the design feature, it is also less vulnerable to collision, he said. Shashi Bhushan Pandey, Chairman of Management Studies & Research Centre (MSRC), Bokaro said, “ It is an international endeavor to replace petroleum propulsion engines with an electric propulsion mechanism for better sustainable development of the society in respect of reduction of suspended particulate matter (SPM).” The children, old age people and population as a whole will not be affected by the smog creating environmental hazards in highly populated cities, said Pandey adding “The decision of ESL to set a target of 2025 to make ESL a company using only electric cars and buses, is highly appreciable and a strong initiative towards sustainable human development.” The idea of no-fly ash is also consistent with environment control since it is no more a pollutant but has become a raw material and ingredient for cement as well as other products using clay, he said.

head: Assistant police personnel end agitation
desc: Assistant police personnel holding protest at the Morabadi ground from the past 12 days for regularization of their job withdrew their agitation on Wednesday following assurance of the State government. Around 2500 assistant police personnel from 12 naxal affected districts of Jharkhand, who were appointed on contractual basis for a period of three years by the previous government headed by Raghubar Das were demanding regularization of their job. As per contract they are getting Rs 10,000 as monthly honorarium. They said that they amount they are getting as honorarium is too low against the service they render. The delegation of agitating assistant police personnel had a marathon meeting with Minister of Water Resource and Sanitation department Mithilesh Thakur. The delegation submitted an eight points memorandum to the Minister and demanded the government to withdraw FIR lodged against assistant police personnel for committing violence during agitation. The Minister assured that their contract period will be extended by the government for another two years and the government will also form a committee to look into the matter. He said that the Hemant Soren government is sympathetic to their demand the process of the formation of the committee will be expedited. The delegation agreed and announced to withdraw agitation after which district administration arranged buses for their transportation to their respective districts.

head: Decorators play band, prepare pandal on road to protest
desc: People of coal city on Wednesday witnessed a unique protest at Randhir Verma Square when suddenly bands started playing marriage related tunes next to road side  mini pandals besides placard holding people around the pandals. This was part of a protest organised by the Decorators Association of Dhanbad that not only formed a human chain but also brought on road the utensils, mining pandals , lighting equipment besides other related items to press for their demand for a hike  in the number of guests during the coming marriage season. Workers of different color related associations that include light and sound ,flower decorators,caterers, generator services and pandal makers took part in the silent demonstration held by maintaining Covid norms. Association district president Pradeep Singh  said ,"Most of us  remain work less for ythe last six months due to cap on guests during the covid period." Singh said, marriage Season that is to commence  soon after the festival season is of limited days according to Hindu panchang  thus permission for hike in guests is needed to save this unorganized business. Singh claimed ,several of the marriages have been postponed due to guest limit. The ban has adversely affected over ten lakh persons related directly or indirectly with aforementioned businesses across Jharkhand. Under this situation we are not even in  position to pay  the employees we have employed ,added Singh while talking to the media here. The most unfortunate part is that though the union government has allowed 100 guests during marriages the Jharkhand government is yet to notify this change. Amidst protests we demand for increasing the guest limit up to 300 in marriage function, demanded Singh.

head: RMC in a fix over operation of city buses
desc: The city bus services of Ranchi Municipal Corporation (RMC) is unlikely to start in the coming days as the corporation is undecided whether the resumption of bus service will be a wise decision in the wake of Covid-19 spreading unchecked. All 91 buses owned by RMC are out of the road right after nationwide lockdown was imposed to stop the spread of Covid-19 virus. After over five months of strict lockdown the state government partially allowed movement of buses when the government allowed intrastate bus service. But the RMC decided not to start bus service which is the lifeline of the city. “Officially, no decision has been taken regarding resumption of bus service. But RMC had indeed discussed as to when and how to start the bus service. The concerned file was sent to Ranchi mayor Asha Lakra but in the meantime she fell ill and till she recovers no decision can be taken on this matter. But chances are dim for early resumption of bus service. We can’t take any decision in a hurry,” said RMC deputy mayor Sanjeev Vijayvargia. RMC hires drivers for the bus service on the basis of certain payment. However, city bus service is not the major source of revenue for RMC but it is a preferred mode of transportation within the city limit by people. Sources in the RMC said that the fare chart will have to be revised since the operational cost of the bus is going to increase. “Now under the new rule a bus can carry passengers only half of the total seats of a bus. Some structural changes will be required inside the bus. In the emerging situation operating buses is not a normal affair. Now a lot of does and don'ts are involved. Like regular sanitization of seats, gate and handlebar, testing of passengers with infrared thermometer. These things require a lot of preparation,” said an official of RMC.

head: Production back on track at Adityapur Industrial Area
desc: Asia’s largest industrial belt, Adityapur Industrial Area is back on the production track. With 80,000 workers back to work, the manufacturing units have revamped their production. Boosted by fresh orders, several industries are also running night shifts to meet the deadlines. City’s leading commercial vehicle maker, Tata Motors has given new orders to manufacture spare parts of 170 trucks per day to the ancillary units. The industrialists are hopeful that with fresh orders production will recover 80 per cent by the end of October. An industrialist, who owns an ancillary unit of Tata Motors in Adityapur, said: “The SME sector is dependent on heavy industries in Jamshedpur. Due to lockdown there was a slump in production. However, the industries have started giving us fresh orders that are helping us to boost production. We are confident that we will be able to recover the production loss by October”.  The sprawling Adityapur Industrial Area houses 1300 units- including 100 large-scale, 550 small scale and 350 tiny industries and most of these units depend on Tata Motors. A few important industries that have global presence are Usha Martin Group, RSB Group, Tata Steel Growth Shop(TGS) etc., too situated in this industrial belt, situated in Seraikela-Kharsawan. There are 20 industries, which export its products to the USA, Australia and other European countries. Sources informed that Tata Motors has also plans to manufacture about 250 vehicles per day from October at its plant and most of the work order will be given to its ancillaries at Adityapur. The move will further improve the industrial activities at the manufacturing hub. Tata Motors produces truck and bus chassis of various models by sourcing parts of the vehicles produced in the ancillary units in the Adityapur industrial area. After the lockdown started on March 25, assembling work at the Tata Motors plant came to a standstill. Ancillary units in Adityapur where some 1 lakh workers work also stopped to function. However, with the third phase of unlocking industrial units are back on the track. “We expect a fresh growth in the manufacturing sector at Adityapur with Tata Motors planning to enhance production. Workers are returning back to work. The move will help to provide fillip to industrial growth in Jharkhand," said Santosh Khetan, Adityapur Small Industries Association (ASIA) functionary and ancillary unit owner.

head: JPCC intensify protest against farm Bill
desc: Jharkhand Pradesh Congress Committee (JPCC) on Wednesday decided that it will intensify protest against the Agricultural Products Trade and Commerce Bill and Agricultural Assurance Agreement bill passed by the Central Government. Addressing media persons here on Wednesday JPCC Chief Rameshwar Oraon said that the anti farmers draconian law will be written with black ink in the history of India. Congress workers will protest against this law against farmers and states in the entire State, he added. JPCC Spokesperson Lal Kishorenath Shahdeo informed that JPCC In-Charge RPN Singh will hold an online press conference on September 24.  "The party will hold a protest near Raj Bhawan against the draconian Act on September, 28 in which almost all senior officials of the party will be present and on October, 28 the party will protest at all district headquarters of the State," he added. A meeting of senior officials of JPCC was convened on Wednesday at the Congress Bhavan to discuss the issue and it was decided that the party will intensify protest against the bill across the State. "The farmers fear that the minimum support price based procurement system will end and exploitation by private companies will increase. The strategy of statewide programs will be decided after the monsoon session. The bill will be opposed in the same way as the Central Government tried to tamper with the Land Acquisition Act," said Oraon. Attacking the Central Government, the JPCC Chief said that the law has been made in accordance with the big industrialists, who wish to dominate the Indian food and agriculture business, which will undermine the bargaining power of farmers. JPCC Spokespersons, Alok Dubey, Lal Kishore Nath Shahdeo and Rajesh Gupta were also present in the meeting. Meanwhile, a delegation of teachers affected by the decision of Jharkhand High Court to cancel the teachers' appointment process, Ranchi, met JPCC Chief Rameshwar Oraon. Oraon assured them that the Government is working for the welfare of them. He said that in this regard, he will also talk to Chief Minister Hemant Soren and it will be tried that their job does not end.

head: IPL betting racket busted, 3 held
desc: Chhattisgarh Police on Wednesday busted an IPL 'satta' (betting) racket operating in Bilaspur city and arrested three persons. Bilaspur Superintendent of Police Prashant Agrawal told the Pioneer that Rs 14,000 in cash as well as betting records detailing transactions of around Rs 50 lakh were seized from them. Those arrested were identified as Ravi Ramani (32) of Godpara, Abhijeet Dueby (32) of Kududand and Luv Verma (32) of Madhya Nagri in the city, the officer said. Seven mobile phones, a LED TV and a set-top box were also seized. Police conducted the raid late on Monday night after getting a tip about a betting racket in Godpara locality in the city on the match played between Rajasthan Royals and Chennai Super Kings, Agrawal said.

head: Fresh lockdown, shutdown, hefty penalty must to save life
desc: The Union Government declared un-lockdown IV rather flatteringly. And most people including the urban intellectuals and the rural wise have gone berserk alike. Even officials, who felt panicky at the beginning with two infections per day, slowly became lax and casual by the time corona became a pandemic. Lockdowns had to be lifted in phases to save people from starvation. But the strategies have been ineffective. When the second lockdown was lifted, even judges of the apex court took the virus lightly and permitted the Puri Car Festival to happen, which definitely sent a wrong signal. The ordinary people began believing that the virulent pathogen was not really so dangerous. Coincidentally, more effective treatment protocols were found out and vaccine candidates showing up were big in number claiming to have passed the first two phases. Except responsible healthcare experts, every other pandemic manager including the ‘warrior’ behaved as if nothing had ever happened.  With un-lockdowns in place, provision markets had big crowds, most of them bumping into each other and without masks, and hand sanitisation only once in a while if the mood was fine. All this time, the virus was having the last laugh, its community multiplying like crazy.  Within two months, most places in India began experiencing a community transmission-like situation though Governments kept screaming, ' everything is under control' by furnishing impressive ratio and proportion of figures and numbers of the infected and deaths against gorier pictures elsewhere. It is now an established truth that careless behaviour and complacency are leading to a spike in Covid-19 cases everywhere, including Odisha which at the initial stage was role model with its timely lockdown and all risk-preventive measures. But when un-lockdowns started happening, without penal measures, at least a 65%-rise was marked in just two months. Corona will not kill many, but the huge pressure it will exert on the inadequate and fragile healthcare systems in most Indian states will for certain cause disaster beyond control. A senior official from the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) in Bhopal expressed concern over the populist Government’s latest guidelines allowing political, social and religious congregations of up to 100 people from September 21. Most other States are following suit as they are frantic to keep people cool. Earlier between March and April, there were corona-positive cases only with mild or no symptoms. That did not require critical care in hospitals. Today, the numbers of the infected have grown astoundingly big. Full-blown Covid cases are too many and most States are finding it difficult to provide matching number of even ordinary beds, let alone ICU facilities with life-supporting gadgets. Besides, medical doctors are proportionately dwindling in number with rising infection among them. There was a great hope that the virus would become weak by September and leave mankind by December though will not leave the planet soon.Until recently, the US was looked upon as the wisest nation with the best remedies for everything, mainly epidemics and pandemics. But they have erred horribly and have become suspect in their treatment methods and protocols. Drawing on a new survey-based research, generated from the Franklin Templeton-Gallup Economics of Recovery Study, it is found that American adults are dramatically misinformed about the mortality risks of Covid-19. On an average, Americans overstate risks to young people by a factor of 46 and understate risks to old people by a factor of two. The average American estimates that 8% of Covid-19 victims are aged 24 and younger, which is suspect. President Trump is a restless person and one in great hurry. He listens to all diverse, contradictory pieces of advice and jumps to bizarre conclusions every second week. Hence, the Americans are suffering more than others elsewhere in the world. Despite wealth and systems in place, the death rate is exceptionally high in the strongest nation of the world. In 2016, 8,970 Americans aged 24 and younger died from road accidents, implying that automobiles are 36 times more deadly than Covid-19. But for the elderly, the risk of dying from Covid-19 is 14 times greater than the risk of dying in an automobile accident. Yet, American officials estimate it to be half that large. So, people did not take corona so very seriously at first. By the time they woke up, much irreparable damage was done already. It’s also true that authorities in the US do not want to see millions of healthy Americans locking themselves up at home, afraid to come across anyone outside their houses, even while wearing a mask and taking other reasonable precautions. These risk-avoidant behaviours have been disastrous to millions of essential workers and small business owners, who provide numerous personal care services. Notably, in Missouri two infected hairdressers did not transmit the virus to any of their clients despite 139 indoor visits in close proximity. The two hairdressers and their customers were all wearing the right-quality masks. But in India, masks are kept in pockets until police personnel are sighted. Or else, they keep hanging from the neck; they are never washed or dried in sun and the make is defective with single layer cloths. Social distancing is the last thing Indians can respect. Lockdowns and shutdowns have to be re-imposed without further delay. The panic of March has to be restored among people anyway. Only workplaces related to economic activities should be permitted to open, which is needed for livelihood and makes physical attendance inevitable.  Use of technology should be dragged to the brim and working online wherever possible be encouraged and rewarded. Videoconferencing can solve numerous ‘one-to-one and group interaction' problems so entertainingly. The containment of coronavirus depends on public awareness. It can be achieved only when people stop making ‘precaution mistakes'. The transmission gets more vigorous than before because of faulty awareness campaigns and approaches. Most of the IEC products scare the public and provoke the common man to begin hating and stigmatising the infected. This has resulted in people and families hiding the fact of infection. And the ‘asymptomatic infected' keep transmitting the virus as super-spreaders. The once-highly lauded Odisha Government permits wedding event congregations not exceeding 50 persons, violating which would attract a penalty of Rs 10,000. The groom, the bride and both the families would also be given exemplary punishment including custodial and pecuniary pain. As the picture is getting more and more frightening in Cuttack, Puri and Khordha districts due to larger flow of people, lockdowns and selective shutdowns have to be imposed forthwith to contain the virus.  The cities of Cuttack, Puri and Bhubaneswar must be taken very seriously. That would certainly save the people effectively. No other strategy appears in sight as of now.

head: Rs 13L brown sugar seized in city
desc: Despite the crackdown by the enforcement agencies, massive seizures and arrest of a number of peddlers, the flow of drugs continues unabated to Bhubaneswar.In an example, the Saheed Nagar police on Wednesday seized 130 gram of brown sugar worth around Rs 13 lakh and arrested two persons in this connection in the city. Acting on inputs, a police team conducted a raid and nabbed two drug peddlers while they were planning to sell the contraband item in the city.“Two persons from Puri district, Nikunja Jagdev and Dhirendra Jaysingh, were nabbed by our special task team and Saheed Nagar police while they were trying to sell brown sugar in Bhubaneswar region today,” said city DCP Umashankar Das. The cops seized 130-gram brown sugar from their possession, he added.

head: Excise Department seizes illegal liquor
desc: The Excise Department on Wednesday seized a huge quantity of 252 Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) bottles valued at Rs 1.80 lakh in Chhattisgarh’s Kabirdham district. Two persons were arrested for transporting it from Madhya Pradesh. An official press release quoted the Kabirdham district Assistant Excise Officer Nitin Kumar Khanduja as saying that the seizure included 28 cartons. The arrested men were identified as the vehicle driver Sanjay Verma (26) and his accomplice Vijay Kumar Yadav (26). Sanjay Verma is from Bhilai and Vijay Kumar from Rajnandgaon in Chhattisgarh, the statement said. Acting on a tip, the Excise Department spotted a SUV and intercepted it near a petrol pump on the Sahaspur-Lohara trijunction in the district. The SUV (CG-04, H-4977) was also seized.

head: OHRC helps youth denied treatment at hospital
desc: The Odisha Human Rights Commission (OHRC) on Wednesday ordered a Bhubaneswar private hospital to conduct surgery of an injured youth who tested positive for Covid-19. Hearing a petition filed by the injured youth’s brother, the OHRC asked the Director of KIMS hospital to immediately undertake surgery of the youth Ranjit Nayak if he is still admitted to the hospital. The cost of the treatment would be borne by the patient, the OHRC stated.In the petition, the injured youth’s brother Pabitra Nayak mentioned Ranjit was taken from one hospital to another for treatment after he suffered a stabbing injury on September 8. Ranjit was taken to Government hospitals like Capital Hospital, SCB Medical College Hospital, Cuttack, and AIIMS, Bhubaneswar, and some private hospitals, but he was turned away as he tested positive for Covid-19. Currently, he is admitted to the KIMS. The OHRC observed that the patient cannot be denied surgery on the plea of Covid-19 infection. The commission also asked the Secretary of the State Health and Family Welfare Department to probe the alleged medical negligence and submit a report during its next hearing on October 15.

head: Former DGP gets Paul H Appleby Award
desc: Indian Institute of Public Administration (IIPA), Bhubaneswar Branch Chairman and former Director General of Police (DGP) Sarat Chandra Misra has been selected to get the prestigious Paul H Appleby Award. This award is given to selected IIPA regional officers for their creativeness, efficiency and achievements each year. The President gives away the award at a special programme organised by IIPA New Delhi.

head: Hirakud water level nears maximum point
desc: The water level in Hirakud reservoir was just below the maximum point of 630 feet on Thursday. Current rains in the upper catchment area in Chhattisgarh due to low pressure in Bay of Bengal worried the dam authorities here as under the present situation with maximum water level (MWL) in hand they have no option than to make the inflow equal to outflow.“But we are relieved a lot as the inflow from Chhattisgarh has reduced drastically due to less rainfall there. The inflow was 2.5 lakh on Tuesday. We have no difficulty at present to handle with the situation with the decreased inflow,” said dam’s Superintend Engineer Bhakta Ranjan Mohanty. He said that the Kalma barrage also didn’t discharge more water during this peak hour.  He said water level would be reduced further if rains occur due to a low pressure expected on September 25. “There is nothing to be panicked now as we as a team are doing our best to handle the situation and we are more watchful towards September last and October first week,” Mohanty said.

head: Go for fish seed production, bamboo handicrafts: CM
desc: Chhattisgarh Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on Wednesday called for the promotion of high- quality fish seed production as well as bamboo handicrafts and farming in medicinal plants. Reviewing the workplan of ‘Livelihood Centres’ at the Gauthans and activities to be made operational at the centres, Baghel laid emphasis on promoting skill development through training in different sectors among the rural youth. He was holding a review meeting at his official residence here. An official statement said the Chief Minister laid stress on development of fisheries across the state for which high quality fish seed production must be promoted. He said the state's fish producers procure better fish seeds from other states. Keeping this in view, the fish producers should be imparted training if high quality and better species fish seed production. Similarly, with availability of bamboo in the state, bamboo handicrafts and farming in medicinal plants, including naturopathy, should be promoted. He stated that training on making of bamboo products to youths in districts where availability of bamboo is higher will provide them employment. In forest areas, medicinal plants farming along with training to establish naturopathy treatment centres will be promoted. These sectors will help bring income. According to Principal Secretary Dr Alok Shukla, it is estimated that around 20,000 youths have been trained in different sectors. The proposal is to produce cattle health worker, producer of organic fertilizer and different materials from cow dung, nursery worker, gardeners and makers of bamboo products among others.

head: BBSR to have uniform heritage signage
desc: The Heritage signage guidelines will further boost the overall beauty and attractiveness of heritage zones of Bhubaneswar, known for its fascinating cultural heritage, amazing temples and monuments by bringing a uniformity in signage design and installation. The signage based on the new guidelines will immensely help visitors, national and international tourists in finding and knowing about various monuments and archaeological sites in the capital city leading to generating awareness among people towards cultural heritage. At present, different types of signages have been installed in Ekamra Kshetra by various agencies leading to visual clutter and absence of proper interpretation signage creates confusion among visitors. Therefore, in 2016, the BDA had identified the need to develop guidelines for unified signage designs for special heritage zones as specified in CDP – 2030.BDA Vice-Chairman Prem Chandra Chaudhary said, “As the Old Town or Ekamra Kshetra of Bhubaneswar is one of the most prominent abodes of Lord Shiva, the heritage signage guideline will bring in a perfect sync with the past and the present as this area is the essence of the State capital." Similar guidelines would also be prepared for other special heritage zones identified under CDP 2030 which will bring uniformity in information dissemination and to improve the overall visitor experience, he added. He further informed that the BDA is also aiming to notify the street design guidelines at the earliest under ODA Rules 2020. The signage guidelines will be applicable to the proposed Heritage District in Bhubaneswar Development Plan Authority as per its Comprehensive Development Plan (CDP)-2030, which includes ‘Ekamra Kshetra Heritage Zone (Old Bhubaneswar), Aitihashik Kshetra Heritage Zone (Sishupalgarh) and Sanskritik Kshetra Heritage Zone (Dhauli). The colour, font, line spacing, paragraph style, arrows and icons, material and scale of all signs should be historically sensitive to monument/building anddistinctiveness of old town area. These signage guidelines will be adopted as part of BDA (Planning and Building standard) Regulations. As per the new guidelines, following six types of signages will be put up at heritage sites such as, directional, interpretative, orientation, facility signage, business and building signage. As per provision of  Odisha Shops and Commercial Establishments (Amendment) Act, 2018, name of a business establishment in the area would be written in Odia language and if required, it can be written in English as a supporting text.

head: CM appreciates ‘Padhai Tuhar Dwar’
desc: Appreciating the ‘Padhai Tuhar Dwar’, Chhattisgarh Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel said Wednesday that it has come as a link with school going children for continuing education during Covid-19. The programme has won kudos across the country. Baghel was holding a review meeting at his official residence. The scheme was launched on April 7, said an official release. Earlier, it was run online but in rural and remote areas due to lack of Internet and Android mobile phones, the programme was extended through offline. The programme of ‘Padhai Tuhar Para’ (Streets) and ‘Bultu App’ was developed. These efforts were welcomed by the Prime Minister and NITI Ayog along with educationists. Under the programme, 2.2 lakh teachers and 23.13 lakh students have been registered. Around 31,792 study materials have been uploaded. Offline classes are being taken by 22,771 teachers and ‘Shiksha Sangwari’ covers 7.60 lakh students.

head: Bharat Ratna for Bijubabu demanded
desc: The Utkal Sammilani on Wednesday demanded that the State Government pass a resolution in the upcoming Assembly session proposing to the Union Government to confer Bharat Ratna to legendary Biju Patnaik posthumously and to put up a statue of Utkalgaurab Madhusudan Das in the Parlemant premises at the earliest.“In an article, the Governor termed Madhubabu as Bharatgaurab. He mentioned that he has not known any other dead body getting covered with national flags of more than one country other than Bijubabu. This assertion of the Governor and our longstanding demand should be considered for fulfillment of our demands forthwith,” said Sammilani’s Mancheswar Industrial Estate Branch president Dillip Dashsharma in a statement. Stating that National Flags of three countries had covered the Bijubabu’s body, Dashsharma said the former Chief Minister’s dedicated service to the nation with unmatchable courage was very rare.  He said the Odisha Government should pass a resolution in line with the Telangana Government to demand establishment of a statue of Madhubabu in Parliament.

head: State Govt discourages Covid test after death
desc: The State Government has discouraged Covid-19 test after death of patients at hospitals to avoid undue delay in release of body and prevent harassment to the bereaved family. An order of the Health Department stated that this decision followed many incidents of relatives and neighbours abstaining from attending funerals and last rites of those testing Covid positive after death. The department has further directed all hospitals treating Covid patients to submit the death report along with the copy of the bed-head tickets, investigation reports and Covid test status to the Director of Health Services (dhsodisha@gmail.com) within 48 hours of the death for the purpose of a State-level death audit. All deaths of Covid patients are audited at the State level to determine the causes of the deaths. All hospitals have also been directed to record all the pre-existing diseases with signs and symptoms at the time of admission along with the related investigation reports and to submit them to the State Level Committee accompanied with the name and contact number of the treating physician.

head: Ensure excellence in Govt English Medium Schools: CM
desc: Ensure excellence both in the teaching and learning processes to students of Government English Medium Schools across Chhattisgarh, Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel said on Wednesday. Emphasis should also be given on developing all infrastructure to impart high quality education, he said at a review meeting of the opening of English Medium Schools in the state. The meeting took place at his residence-cum-office here with School Education Minister Dr Premsai Singh Tekam and senior government officials, an official release said. Seeing the encouraging response from parents, the benchmark of the Government English Medium School is to provide better quality education than the private schools, the Chief Minister said. He said the initial plan was to begin a school in each district headquarters. But with demand rising, the number has increased to 51. “Go for parallel planning of 146 English Medium Schools in each block of the state from next academic     session. The training of    teachers should also be ensured,” said Baghel. School Education Department Principal Secretary Dr Alok Shukla said that Durg district has plans for 10 schools, Balrampur 4, Raipur, Korba and Bilaspur 3 each, Janjgir-Champa, Bemetara, Korea, Gaurela-Pendra-Marwahi and Surguja 2 each and the other districts one school each. The principals have been appointed and teachers’    appointment is in progress. A total of 27,741 students have been admitted and online classes have begun.

head: Punjab gives 3 month extension from Oct 1 to doctors below 60
desc: The Punjab Government on Wednesday gave a three months extension from October 1 to doctors who are below the age of 60 years. “In wake of COVID-19, all doctors who are 58 years and plus below the age of 60 years are given a three months extension from October 1, 2020, to December 31, 2020. Earlier, the extension was given from April 1, 2020, to September 30, 2020,” said the state Health and Family Welfare Minister Balbir Singh Sidhu. The Minister clarified that all doctors who have attained the age of 60 years as on September 30, 2020, will be retired. All specialist doctors, who will be retired, have the option of re-employment as per rules and guidelines.

head: Ensure adequate medical oxygen supplies for Punjab from other States: Capt to Modi
desc: Amid apprehensions of shortage of medical oxygen with rising cases, Punjab Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Wednesday urged the Prime Minister Narendra Modi to direct urgent steps to ensure adequate supplies from other states. At the same time, the Chief Minister also sought expeditious release of Rs 200 crore that the State Government had requested as the next tranche of central aid for COVID-19 management. With experts suggesting possible aggravation of COVID-19 conditions due to stubble burning, the Chief Minister also reiterated his demand for fiscal aid by the Centre to farmers for defraying the cost on management of paddy straw. The CM maintained that even though the State Govt is launching an aggressive media campaign to educate farmers and people in general, giving the linkage with COVID-19, he insisted that it was imperative for the Central Government to step in with the Rs 100 per quintal compensation the State has been seeking for the farmers to manage the paddy straw. During a virtual meeting with the PM, the Chief Minister also urged him to direct the Chief Controllers of Explosives, Nagpur, to clear the license request for establishment of a liquid medical oxygen plant at Government Medical College, Patiala, by HLL India Limited, under the PM Swasthya Surkhsha Yojna (PMSSYSY). The Prime Minister, while promising to look into the Chief Minister’s requests, suggested that the State Government should strengthen its COVID-19 awareness efforts by involving the civil society even more aggressively and making announcements from Gurdwaras and other religious places. Modi also expressed confidence that Punjab would be able to reduce the positivity rate to less than five percent and bring down the COVID Fatality Rate (CFR). ON SUPPLY OF MEDICAL OXYGEN Noting that government and private hospitals in Punjab could end up facing shortage of medical Oxygen supply due to the late surge of COVID-19 cases, Capt Amarinder informed the PM that with no manufacturers of medical oxygen, the State was largely dependent on three big manufacturers for liquid oxygen — Baddi (Himachal Pradesh), Dehradun (Uttarakhand), and Panipat (Haryana). Dehradun and Panipat plants are not supplying oxygen as per the state’s demand, he said, adding that the Panipat plant can supply more oxygen if supply to Panipat Refinery is curtailed. “Punjab Government, on its part, is in talks with industry to convert industrial oxygen to medical oxygen,” he said. ON FISCAL PACKAGE FOR COVID Demanding financial assistance, the Chief Minister pointed out that the Central Govt has released Rs 131.22 crore from the Covid-19 Emergency Response Fund, and after submitting a Utilization Certificate for the whole amount, the State had requested the Centre for immediate release of Rs 200 crore, which is awaited. “The Govt of India was requested to reconsider the limit of 35% expenditure for COVID relief under SDRF from the overall availability of the resource envelope, but the Centre is still continuing with 35 percent limit on SDRF for COVID on yearly basis,” he pointed while requesting the PM to make this limit as overall limit or removed altogether as the pandemic is going to stay for a long time. STRENGTHENING MEDICAL INFRASTRUCTURE To further strengthen the state’s fight against COVID-19, the Chief Minister also requested that installation of ventilators provided by the Centre be completed at the earliest. He also pointed out the complaints of their malfunctioning by both public and private healthcare institutions. The Chief Minister urged the Centre to direct the PGIMER, Chandigarh, to add more ICU beds, and also to strengthen their Satellite Centre at Sangrur and initiate work in Ferozepur, as requested even earlier. AIIMS, Bathinda may be asked to increase beds for COVID, which is currently only 20, he added. STATE’s COVID STATUS Updating the Prime Minister on the state’s COVID situation, Capt Amarinder said that the last three to four weeks had seen surge in cases, and, on an average, in the past week, around 2400-2500 cases and around 55-60 mortalities were reported daily.  “The main concern is the Case Fatality Ratio (CFR), which remains high at 2.9 percent despite some reduction in the past one week,” he said while listing several measures being undertaken to check CFR, especially in the nine worst-affected districts of the state. ON HINDRANCES “The major problem is the casual (chalda hai) attitude of Punjabis, who do not take minor symptoms seriously. The problem has been compounded by the ongoing protests, where even certain parties, like Lok Insaaf Party, have been spreading propaganda against the need to wear masks,” he said, adding that 25 percent people, especially in congested areas, were not wearing masks and the police had been fining 4,000 to 5,000 violators every day. The Chief Minister also referred to the recent “disinformation campaign” by mischief mongers, some of whom had political links also and had been carrying out a very organized campaign, terming COVID as a conspiracy by Governments of India and Punjab and spreading false information on harvesting of organs. “This became very active on social media, and some panchayats passed resolutions against testing, videos went viral and a general perception of fear was created among people against COVID testing,” he said adding that the situation had now improved, and the state is currently doing around 30,000 tests daily on both RT-PCR and RAT, and aims to take it to 40,000 soon.

head: Training prog on SCA,TPPRA, MHA inaugurated
desc: For the first time three day, training on Senior Citizen Act, Transgender Person Protection of Rights Act and Mental Health Act was inaugurated on Wednesday at the state police headquarters. The training division of state police headquarters is starting a three-day training webinar. Training will be imparted on the first day on Senior Citizen Act-2017, on the second day Transgender Person Protection of Rights Act-2019 and on the third day Mental Health Act-2017. For the first time in the country, by providing training on these subjects, the training division of Madhya Pradesh Police Headquarters is setting new benchmarks even during the corona transition period. Assistant Inspector General of Police (Training) Malay Jain informed that on September 25, on the second day of the webinar, Special Director General of Police (Training) Aruna Mohan Rao will deliver the inaugural address. Lakshmi Narayan Tripathi, Member National Council for Transgender will deliver lecture. On this subject, Director of the National Resource Center for Transgender Prof. Aryan Pasha, Member of National Council for Transgender, Rajesh Kumar, Ganga Kumari, Police Constable of Jalore, Rajasthan and K. Prathika Yashini, Deputy Inspector of Police, Tamil Nadu will deliver lecture. The event is being organized by the National Institute of Social Defense, Government of India and Madhya Pradesh Police Academy, Bhopal.

head: 3-day Natya Sangeet festival concluded with daughter’s musical tribute to father
desc: The Bhopalites witnessed a startling evening with daughter giving tribute to her father through a musical programme. A three day Natya Sangeet festival concluded at Madhya Pradesh School of  (MPSD) on Wednesday. To remember the works and contribution of one of the noted theatre personality Habib Tanvir, Nagin Tanvir presented a musical programme under Natya Sangeet Festival. The songs composed by Habib Tanvir and the songs presented in his plays were presented beautifully. Prior to the event, Alok Chhatterjee, Director of MPSD informed that due to heavy rain in the city, audience is requested to watch the live telecast of the show on MPSD Facebook Live page. He also said that all the precautionary measures are been taken in COVID 19 scenario. Notably, Habib Tanvir was one the pioneers of theatre industry. He created a niche for the upcoming theatre artist across the nation. Also, his plays have created a benchmark across the world in the theatre industry. His plays like Chandrahas Chor, Goun Naam Sasural Mor Naam Damad and many others are like stepping stones for the young theatre artists. This programme was a tribute to Habib Tanvir and his contribution in the theatre industry. It is also known that music played a vital role in the plays of Habib Tanvir. Tanvir always paid attention to the music and its presentation. The songs and musical instruments used in his plays were phenomenal. All the plays had a different kind of music according to the concept. If it was a folk play the music was also according to it and vice versa. The selected songs of his plays were presented here on Monday in the programme. The songs were presented by known Thumri singer and daughter of Habib Tanvir Nagin Tanvir. She gave a splendid performance of the songs that were used in Habib Tanvir’s plays. The audience was overwhelmed with this performance.

head: Sukhbir expresses shock, anguish at ‘bulldozing’ of J&K Official Languages Bill in Parliament
desc: Expressing shock and anguish at the manner in which the Jammu and Kashmir Official Languages Bill, 2020, was “bulldozed” in the Parliament, the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) president Sukhbir Singh Badal on Wednesday said that it was condemnable that the voice of the people of Jammu and Kashmir in support of Punjabi language had been muzzled. “It is a matter of deep concern that parliamentary procedures have not been followed while putting up the Bill for approval before Parliament. The Bill was neither put on the agenda of the Lok Sabha yesterday nor the Rajya Sabha today. Even today, it was passed at the last minute in the absence of the opposition,” said Sukhbir. This is the second time that the SAD which is already standing against its ally, the BJP, on the issue of farm bills, has lashed out on the saffron party for “misusing” its “brute majority” to pass a bill in the House. Earlier, the Akali Dal criticized the way the farm bills were passed in both the Houses — Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha — allegedly ignoring rules. Sukhbir condemned that the Bill was taken up for approval without taking into consideration the objections of SAD as well as other regional parties of Jammu and Kashmir. “While speaking in the Lok Sabha, I had pointed out that Punjabi is not only the mother tongue of a large number of people of the Union Territory but is also a recognized language as per the Constitution of the erstwhile State of Jammu and Kashmir,” he pointed. He added, “Dr Farooq Abdullah of the National Conference, who is a former Chief Minister of Jammu and Kashmir, supported me and said that a sizable number of Kashmiris also spoke Punjabi. The Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) has also supported the inclusion of Punjabi as an official language in the union territory”. Terming the entire development as a “sad day for democracy”, Sukhbir said that the founding fathers of the Constitution were inspired by a vision of India as a multi religious, multicultural and multilingual nation and respect for regional languages was seen an important tool to preserve and promote this ideal. He also expressed anguish that while Punjabi had been excluded from the list of official languages, English had been included in the list. “This is sure to hurt the sentiments of Punjabis in Jammu and Kashmir as well as everywhere else”, he added.

head: Guest lecture held on tenth day of Hindi fest ‘Toornayad’
desc: On the tenth day of Toornayad a guest lecture was organised at Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology (MANIT).  Chinmay Pandya, the vice-chancellor of Dev Sanskriti University was present as the guest speaker on Wednesday. Toornayad is the Hindi festival organised every year at MANIT. it invites students from all technical colleges of the country to participate in various events. He addressed the youngsters on Self Reliant India and self-reliance.  Chinmaya Pandya left his job as a doctor in England and returned to India with a sense of service to the motherland. Since 2010, he has been continuously serving as the vice-chancellor of Dev Sanskriti University, as well as playing important responsibilities in much-reputed Government and non-Governmental organizations at the national and international level. More important than being self-reliant it is to depend on oneself. Starting his speech with the utterance of Gayatri Mahamantra,  Chinmay said that more important than being self-reliant is to depend on the soul. He said that today’s odd circumstances create terror in the human mind, but at the same time, it gives good and awakened souls the determination to do something and come forward. Highlighting the present circumstances, Pandya said that whatever be the external form of today’s society, but the internal is hollow. The faster the size of homes has grown, the faster the family is limited. Today, doubt, doubt and harshness have taken the place of belonging, affection and trust from the heart of man.  That is why today there is a need for awakened souls to come forward and elevate humanity from this dark environment. Citing the story of King Bharata and Narada Muni, Pandya said that instead of conquering everything, we need a victory over our personality. We value internal excellence rather than external achievements because it is impossible to take away. At the end of the lecture, the committee’s alumni president, Abhilash Pateria, thanked Chinmaya Pandya and extended his best wishes to the event.

head: No party has misguided farmers, says Haryana Bhartiya Kisan Union prez
desc: Claiming that no political party has misguided the farmers over the agriculture bills passed in Parliament, Haryana Bhartiya Kisan Union president Gurnam Singh Chaduni on Wednesday said that farmers are fully aware about the farm bills and they are just seeking a law which ensures assured Minimum Support Price (MSP) for crops. Talking to The Pioneer on phone, he said that the legislators of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and Jannayak Janata Party (JJP) should listen to their inner voice and join agitation against anti-farmer bills. He said the agitation has received a warm response from labourers to traders despite the Centre and BJP- ruled State Government’s campaign in favour of these bills. “We have appealed to the traders and shopkeepers to shut down their establishments in support of farmers against these bills. The peaceful agitation has been called and will further be intensified in coming days," he added.
