Chaduni who is leading farmers’ agitation against Centres’ three contentious farm bills in Haryana claimed that the State has witnessed such a big stir after many years. The Farmer's Produce Trade and Commerce (Promotion and Facilitation) Bill, 2020 and the Farmers (Empowerment and Protection) Agreement of Price Assurance and Farm Services Bill, 2020, were passed by the Upper House recently through voice vote despite objection from farmers. He said, “We hope that MLAs of BJP and JJP will listen to their inner voice and would come forward in support of farmers who have been demonstrating the passage of agricultural reform bills in the parliament.” He alleged that through these passed bills, the ruling party is trying to benefit the big business. Asked whether these bills have become political, Chaduni said that this has become people’s issue as the opposition did not play its due role when three ordinances were introduced. They are playing a better role now after farmers stir picked up. Responding to a question that Haryana Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar has recently appealed to farmers to talk to the State Government, he said, “BJP Government had never invited farmers for talks to redress their concerns in the past few years. We are ready to talk to the Government if they invite us to discuss issues pertaining to farmers of the State.” Responding to the question that Haryana Chief Minister also assured farmers' of not ending the MSP of crops, he said that if this system is not being ended, then why maize was not purchased at the rate of MSP. In place of MSP of Rs 1,760 per quintal, the farmers sold maize to private players in the range of just Rs 800 to 1,100 per quintal. Why did (the government agencies) procure only 25 per cent of total gram (at the rate of MSP)? The government is withdrawing its hand from offering support price to the crops of farmers. Asked about the BJP's charge that farmers are being misguided by the opposition leaders, Chaduni said that no one can misguide the farmers. This issue is not related to Congress, JJP and BJP but of the people of the country. He alleged that JJP has failed to raise the voice of Haryana farmers. “If Dushyant wants to keep hopes of farmers alive, he should move out of the alliance government in the interest of the farmers. Farmers gave Dushyant votes with the hope that he will work for their welfare. He got the anti-BJP votes. But in his hunger for power, he has put all those votes in the pocket of the BJP. The BJP has now brought out a death warrant for the farming sector. He should withdraw support from the BJP-JJP government.” On the recent hike in MSP for Rabi crops, he said that the hike in the MSP is insufficient in comparison to the rate of inflation. Normally, the MSP is declared at the end of October or initial period of November, but this time they have declared it one and half months in advance. This is just an attempt to convince the farmers that MSP is not being discontinued. Chaduni further said that with the passage of these bills in both the Houses of the parliament, now the entire agriculture business will go into the hands of few private capitalists. Agricultural produce will go to them and people of the country will purchase food grains from them at much higher prices. Currently, the government purchases food grains and supplies to the poor (at cheaper rates) as the government doesn't believe in profit making. Farmers are just seeking a law from the Union Government which ensures assured Minimum Support Price (MSP) of the crops, he added.

head: Haryana witnesses 27 more Covid deaths, 1,986 fresh cases
desc: Haryana on Wednesday witnessed 27 more fatalities due to Covid-19, taking the death toll to 1,233, while 1,986 fresh cases pushed the State's infection tally to 116,856.Of the new deaths, three each were reported from Ambala and Rohtak; two  each from Gurugram, Karnal, Bhiwani, Kurukshetra, Sirsa and Yamunanagar and one each from Faridabad, Panipat, Hisar, Panchkula, Mahendergarh and Fatehabad, according to the state health department's daily bulletin.Among the districts which reported a high spike in cases are Gurugram (286), Faridabad (262), Hisar (215), Panchkula (146), Sonepat (131), Ambala (125), Karnal (117) and Kurukshetra (100). The number of active Covid-19 cases in the State is 19,276, while 96,347 patients have been discharged after recovery. As many as 2,571 patients were discharged after recovery in the last 24 hours. As of Wed, the state has a recovery rate of 82.45 per cent and the fatality rate is 1.06 per cent. The rate at which infections are doubling is 27 days and Covid-19 positivity rate is 6.67 per cent, as per the bulletin.

head: TSML starts operation at Sukinda mine
desc: The Tata Steel Mining Limited (TSML), formerly known as TS Alloys Ltd, commenced operations at its Sukinda chromite mine on Monday. The groundbreaking ceremony to kick-start the mining operations at Sukinda was attended by TSML managing director MC Thomas, seneior general manager Sushanta Mishra and senior officials of the TSML and Dhanshar Engineering & Co. Pvt Ltd (DECO), the mine developer and operator (MDO) for the mine.  “It is a significant milestone for theTata Steel Mining and the first step in our journey of commercial mining. As a responsible corporate, the Tata Steel Mining is committed to sustainable mining practices and excellence in governance while treating all its stakeholders as partners in long term value creation,” said Thomas.

head: K'pada Covid hosp X-ray machine, oximeter defunct
desc: Close on the heels of a viral video on stray dogs taking rest at the isolation wards of the district headquarters hospital in Kendrapada set off furor, another allegation of sheer apathy and mismanagement of the Covid Care Hospital in the district has come to the fore.  A Covid positive patient, who has been admitted  at the Covid care hospital in Chhata –based Government polytechnic college, failed to have his chest X-ray done there as the X-ray machine was dysfunctional. The patient brought the matter to the notice of this correspondent over phone. Chandan Kumar Singh, an employee of District Labour Office, on Saturday suffered from cold and fever. As a result, he was in home isolation. Later, he was detected positive for Covid, for which he was taken to the Covid care hospital set up here by the district administration  in collaboration with Bhubaneswar-based SUM hospital.He brought the matter to the notice of the Sub-Collector on the non-functioning of the X-ray machine and demanded him to be shifted either to Covid unit at Cuttack-based Ashwini Hospital or Bhubaneswar-based SUM Hospital. He also alleged that  when he reached at Covid care hospital of the district, he was  examined with oximeter, but he alleged that the Oximeter did not show any reading. Even, the bathroom and urinal were lying unhygienic.Notably, Singh is the nephew of Rajya Sabha MP Subash Singh.When contacted, Sub-Collector Jyotishankar Mohapatra, informed that he would take necessary steps in the issue.

head: 96 kg ganja seized; one held
desc: The Crime Branch’s Special Task Force (STF) on Tuesday seized a huge cache of ganja and arrested a person in this connection from Barabati village under the Begunia police station in Khordha district. Based on reliable inputs, the STF conducted a raid and seized 96 kg of the contraband and nabbed one Dinabandhu Mohapatra of Barabati village. A case has been registered at Begunia police station under Sections 20 (b)(ii)(c) of NDPS Act 1985 f. Further investigations are on in connection with incident, said an official.

head: Covid victims’ cremation sparks row
desc: The cremation of two Covid-19 deceased at the College Chhack crematorium here on Tuesday has triggered strong resentment among locals.Report said that the two patients succumbed to the virus while undergoing treatment at the District Headquarters Hospital.When the municipal authorities brought the bodies from cremation as per the Covid norms, the locals staunchly opposed and said the move can spread the virus in adjoining areas. Facing stiff opposition, the municipal team returned back and informed district administration.  Later, police along with a Magistrate, municipality Covid Nodal officer and Health Officer reached spot and bodies were cremated.

head: 12.5-ft python in Puri village
desc: Residents of Podakera village under Balabhadrapur gram panchayat in Puri district were panicked when a giant python was spotted in the locality early on Wednesday morning. Locals first spotted the 12.5-feet Burmese python in a bushy area and raised an alarm. People in large numbers gathered at the spot to have a look at the huge reptile. Later, the villagers called up the Puri Snake Helpline. Soon after, snake-catcher Sangram Keshari reached the spot and rescued the python with the help of locals.The python weighing around 16 kg was a male and believed to be of 10 years old. Later, the snake was handed over to the forest officials in Puri.

head: PM b’day: Ganjam BJP holds plantation drive
desc: As a part of “Seva Saptah” (service week from September 14 to 20) celebrated country wide by the party on the eve of 70th birthday of the Prime Minister Narendra Modi, the BJP’s Ganjam unit organised a plethora of social welfare programmes across the district to mark the event with great enthusiasm, said former district president of the party and senior leader Kanhu Charan Pati here. On the last day of the “Seva Saptah”, the San Bazar Mandal of the party organised a massive tree plantation camp in the premises of “Brahmapur Jateeya Sangeet Kala Kendra”.  Hundreds of plants of various species and medicinal values were planted by the party workers praying a healthy and long life of the Prime Minister.The plantation programme was undertaken under the coordination of the San Bazar Mandal BJP president Saroj Patra. Among others, Prabhat K Sadangi, N Rajendra Kumar, Subhasini Pattnaik, Srinivas Subudhi, Pranay Mahapatra, Kumar Purohit, Arun Panigrahi, Suman Satapathy, S Srinivas, Binayak Rath, Ram Babu Subudhi, Rajesh Kumar Senapati, T Sabat, Prabir Patra, Kiran Mohanty, Murali Rao and hundreds of youth leaders of the party joined. Addressing the workers, Pati said that such welfare and people-friendly works will be carried out by the party in the coming days.

head: MoU for Paradip crude oil land reclamation
desc: For the first time, maintenance dredging material would be utilised for land reclamation of the Numaligarh Refinery Limited (NRL) storage terminal at Paradip. Unoin Minister of Shipping Mansukh Mandavyia has been encouraging Ports for such beneficial reuse of dredge material. This is a unique initiative being taken by the Dredging Corporation of India (DCI) with the Paradip Port Trust (PPT) and the NRL. The NRL on Wednesday entered into a tripartite memorandum of understanding (MoU) with the PPT and the DCI for reclamation of the proposed 200 acres of land allotted to the NRL for setting up its crude oil import terminal (COIT) at Paradip Port.The MoU was signed by PPT Conservator Capt AK Mahapatra, DCI CGM Capt S Divakar and NRL DGM (Projects Pipeline) AJ Phukan in presence of PPT Chairman Rinkesh Roy, NRL MD SK Barua and DCI MD Rajesh Tripathi, among others.The terminal is being set up as part of NRL’s Rs 22,000-crore integrated Refinery Expansion project. The mega project envisages, amongst others, import of crude oil at the Paradip Port and laying of pipeline to Numaligarh to transport the same.  Project activities have gathered pace after receipt of the environmental clearance  in July 2020.The DCI would start the dredging activity from mid-November 2020 and is expected to complete the reclamation work of COIT plot within a period of seven months.

head: Nod to phase 3 clinical trial of COVAXIN
desc:
|
The Uttar Pradesh government has given permission to Bharat Biotech International Limited for the third phase clinical trial of COVID-19 vaccine COVAXIN in Lucknow and Gorakhpur.
Additional Chief Secretary (Health) Amit Mohan Prasad in his order on Wednesday said that Sanjay Gandhi Post-Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences (SGPGI) Director Dr RK Dhiman would be the nodal official for Lucknow and BRD Medical College Principal Dr Ganesh Kumar would be the nodal officer for Gorakhpur.
The approval letter sent to Bharat Biotech Director Dr V Krishna Mohan says: “Refer to your letter dated September 19, 2020 addressed to the undersigned requesting for permission to seek approval and facilitation to initiate COVAXIN TM Phase 3 Efficacy and Safety clinical trial in Uttar Pradesh.
“I am pleased to inform you that after due consideration, it has been decided to allow Bharat Biotech to conduct phase 3 trial in Lucknow and Gorakhpur respectively.”
Prasad said all required approvals would have to be obtained by the company and all safety and other protocols would have to be followed as per the guidelines of the Government of India for conducting clinical trials.

head: Inebriated, sparring cops suspended in Bahraich
desc:
|

Creating a ruckus after getting inebriated at a party organised by a colleague and sullying the image of UP Police proved costly for eight cops in Bahraich as they were suspended by the district police chief.
A probe was also ordered into the matter to initiate departmental proceedings against the errant cops.
As per reports, constable Mahip Shukla posted at Risia police station threw a party on Sunday night. At the party, his colleagues in uniform consumed alcohol and engaged in fisticuffs. The incident was not reported to the senior officers. However, the entire sequence of events surfaced on the social media bringing disrepute to the police force.
As soon as the incident came to his knowledge, Superintendent of Police of Bahraich, Vipin Misra, suspended all the eight policemen.
The suspended cops included party organiser Mahip Shukla, constables Rajesh Yadav, Amit Yadav, Ajay Yadav, Pankaj Yadav, Vinod Yadav, Pawan Yadav and Afzal Khan.
The district police chief also initiated a probe and asked ASP (City) Kunwar Gyananjay Singh to submit a report in this context.

head: Widespread showers likely on Sept 23-24
desc: A low pressure system present in the Bay of Bengal caused an increase in the rainfall activity across the State and also helped revive monsoon towards the end of the third week of September. The dry spell witnessed during the second week of the month was overcome with widespread showers which is likely to continue for the next few days. According to the weather bulletin released on September 22 by the Meteorological Centre, Ranchi, on September 23 the north eastern parts of the State are likely to witness heavy showers accompanied with thunderstorm and lightning. Fairly widespread rainfall of light to moderate category is being forecasted for September 24. On September 25 parts of north eastern and south eastern districts might receive some rainfall while on September 26 places in the north east could witness thunderstorm activity. “From September 20 the low pressure system present in the Bay of Bengal was having an impact over Jharkhand which caused widespread showers on September 21 and 22. This has also brought the rainfall departure down to -13 and towards the end of the monsoon season Jharkhand will witness near normal conditions. All observations made by the MET Centre, Ranchi have been very accurate for all the low pressure systems throughout the monsoon season and this has greatly benefitted the people of Jharkhand,” said Deputy Director MET Centre, Ranchi Abhishek Anand. As per the statistics released by the MET Centre, Ranchi, from June 1 to September 22, Jharkhand has received a total of 868.1 mm of rainfall as against the actual amount of 999.3 mm while the present monsoon departure has been recorded at -13 percent. As many as 10 districts namely Deoghar (-44), Godda (-22), Pakur (-29), Jamtara (-21), Garwah (-23), Chatra (-32), Saraikela- Kharsawan (-27), Gumla (-51), Bokaro (-23) and Khunti (-24) are facing a rainfall deficit while the remaining have witnessed normal or near normal monsoon. As per the communiqué, from September 23 to September 26 the maximum temperature in Ranchi and its surrounding areas will be around 29- 30 degree Celsius.

head: PNS
desc: The Ranchi district administration has lodged First Information Reports (FIRs) against at least 170 travelers in the past two months for violating home quarantine norms after returning to the Jharkhand capital from other states, officials said. “Around 170 people have been booked under sections of the Disaster Management Act in Ranchi in the past two months for violating home quarantine norms. These include travelers from other states, and the ones who returned to Ranchi,” said Ranchi Sub Divisional Officer, Sameera S. The violators were booked under sections of the Disaster Management Act in Ranchi for leaving their homes during the mandatory 14-day quarantine period and posing risk to the wellbeing of other citizens, officials from the district administration said. The government, officials added, was committed to ensuring that travelers from other states, and the ones who return to Jharkhand after visiting other states, must stay in home quarantine for 14 days or face legal consequences. The district administration constituted special teams to keep a tab on such travelers. During inspections, the teams found that many people, supposed to stay at home, were either going to offices, visiting relatives and even going to banks and other public places, sources said. In the wake of Covid-19 pandemic, the government had on July 17 made it mandatory for all visitors from other states to stay in home quarantine for at least 14 days. Officials in Jharkhand also put VIPs like Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) MP Sakshi Maharaj on 14-day quarantine when he visited Giridih last month. He was not allowed to leave until he tested negative for Covid-19. Earlier in August, concerned authorities also lodged an FIR against Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) leader Tej Prasad Yadav for allegedly violating lockdown rules. As per the Jharkhand Contagious Disease Ordinance, a person violating the preventive measures for Covid-19 could be slapped a fine of up to Rs.1 lakh and imprisoned for up to two years. Ranchi is the worst-affected district in Jharkhand in terms of Covid cases. As per records with the health department, as many as 15,707 cases of Covid-19 infection have surfaced in the district so far, which is around 25 per cent of the total Covid tally in Jharkhand. The district has also reported 101 Covid casualties, which is the second highest among all 24 districts in Jharkhand.  The district administration here recently started door-to-door screening of Ranchi residents to identify asymptomatic cases of infection and spread awareness among commoners. It has also constituted teams to monitor oxygen level of asymptomatic Covid patients in home isolation.

head: Govt failed to secure interest of tribals, natives, says BJP
desc: The State BJP on Tuesday attacked the Hemant Soren led government on the recruitment policy issue. Reacting sharply to the Chief Minister's statement on the recruitment policy at a press conference here on Tuesday, State BJP spokesperson Pratul Shahdeo said that this government is not able to protect the interests of tribal and indigenous people of the State. On the decision of the High Court, Shahdeo said that the government did not present its right side on the recruitment policy of the erstwhile Raghuvar government. Pratul said that the local policy framed by the Raghuvar government was upheld by the  High Court, but this government could not defend the recruitment policy properly, which created a job crisis on thousands of tribal native youth. He said that when the Hemant government could not protect the 1985 cutoff date, what would it be able to do on the cutoff date of 1932. That is why the BJP clearly believes that this government is a useless government. He said that to protect the officers, the government takes help of renowned counsels to strongly present the government’s side in the court, but when there is a matter of protecting the employment of tribal native youth of the State, the government does not bring lawyers like Harish Salve and Nariman to put the State’s side. Pratul said that if the state government had been friendly to the tribal natives, the Supreme Court would have intervened in the 'Leela Prasad Rao' case of Andhra Pradesh because the decision had far-reaching effects on Jharkhand. Pratul said that the Supreme Court had also ruled in the decision of Vikas Pratap Singh v. Government of Chhattisgarh that the earlier appointments would not be affected, but the State Government did not put its stand in the High Court in a good way. Para 47 of the High Court decision clearly states that there is no restriction on the appointment of assistant candidates to the Panchayat Secretary, but the government has held this appointment for a long time. Pratul said that after the year 2017, all the appointments of classes three and four in the State have been done from the local residents of Jharkhand. He said that the state government only makes unreal announcements to give jobs to the local people but it is not intended to give employment to the tribal native youth of the State. Spokesperson Pradeep Sinha and State media in-charge Shivpujan Pathak were also present at the press conference.

head: in brief
desc: ECR holds events during Rajbhasha fortnight Several programmes are being organised on the occasion of Rajbhasha Fortnight being observed by East Central Railway between Sptember 14 and 25. The programmes include Hindi Essay Competition, employees’ quiz and other events, which were organised through virtual means. During the quiz questions from promoting the national language, art and culture were also asked. The events are being organised under the guidance of GM ECR LC Trivedi.   SBI donates clothes, cash for Corona affected State Bank of India, SARB, Ranchi with the self help organisation called ‘Goonj’ will be conducting a program called ‘Joy of Giving’ from September 1 to September 30. Under this campaign all staff members of the branch have donated clothes and an amount of Rs 53651 for people affected by the Corona epidemic. Assistant General Manager of the branch Daya Shankar urged the staff members to actively participate in the campaign and give more donations. Chief Manager Neelam Manisha Khes, Rakesh Kumar, Pankaj Kumar and others were present on the occasion   2 get Life term in Hazaribag After five years of the murder of Sushil Shrivastava the final verdict came out from the court on Tuesday. A Hazaribag court awarded life imprisonment to two main accused Vikash Tiwary and and Santosh Pandey in Sushil Srivasatav murder case on Tuesday. Three others who helped them in the execution of the crime were also sentenced life imprisonment and fine. The court sentenced life imprisonment to the prime accused under section 302 and 120 (b), two years of jail under section 341 and a fine of rupees 66,000. The court also sentenced life imprisonment to three other accused Vishal Singh, Rahul Dev Pandey and Dilip Sao fine along with 60,000. Prior to this decision the court was declared all the five accused guilty on September 11.   Tata Steel Sr manager dies in mishap Tata Steel’s senior manager operations, CRM at Jamshedpur Steel Works died in a mishap on Tuesday morning. Aged 27, Sheeraz Zama Khan was in the C-shift duty and got entrapped in the exit looper of the galvanizing line and lost his life.According to information, the victim was attending to a fault in the line. Tata Steel has started investigation into the mishap and the area around the accident has been cordoned off. Kulvin Suri, chief, corporate communications, India & SEA, Tata Steel in a communiqué said: “ The family of Sheeraz Zama Khan has been informed and the company expresses deep sense of grief and stands by the family in this difficult moment in time. The family will receive all support as per the company’s policy. Tata Steel is committed to the health and safety of its employees and continuously strives towards ensuring a safe workplace for all its employees”.   Campus placements begins at ICFAI Campus Placement Season has started at ICFAI University, Jharkhand, wherein Prof O R S Rao, Vice-Chancellor of the University addressed all the final year students through Video Conference. Explaining the challenges in the current job market for fresh graduates, Prof O R S Rao said, “Due to COVID-19 Pandemic, all the sectors of the economy are going through stress and disruption. All organisations are going through digital transformation. So, all of you have to acquire digital skills not only to get good campus placement but also to succeed as a professional.  All students must know how to use Social Media, like Linked In, for professional networking and self-development”.   24x7 Newswire turns one 24x7 Newswire on its one-year celebration today took the opportunity to highlight the importance of digital optimization and how a brand can re-define their business goals and objectives through digital/social platforms in today’s day and age. 24x7 Newswire is one such digital media startups that has established itself as one of the fastest growing online news platforms in India and have accomplished itself in the world of digital media in this one year. Known for having a strong presence in the regional market with access to wires and 100+ news portals like Outlook, equityBulls, Adgully, Rediff, etc, 24x7 Newswire gives 100% SEO benefits to its clients to help your website rank high.

head: Vijay Deo Jha
desc: A day after Jharkhand High Court judgment striking down 100 percent quota in class III and class IV jobs in scheduled districts of Jharkhand; the ruling JMM said that the government will formulate ‘local residence and employment policy for Jharkhand’ afresh. On Monday Jharkhand High Court scrapped recruitment process of high school teachers issued by the government in 2016 under which the government had prescribed 100 per cent reservation to local residents in 13 scheduled districts. The high court also declared all appointments made against the said advertisement to be null and void which is set to render as many 5,000 teachers jobless. Advertisement for teachers’ appointment was issued a few months after the then BJP-Ajsu Party led government headed by Raghubar Das introduced local residence and employment policy for Jharkhand. 1985 was fixed as the cut off year to fix domicile status for residence and the government also formulated a rule for 100 percent appointment to local residents of scheduled districts in the government job. Addressing a press conference at the party office on Tuesday afternoon; JMM general secretary Suprio Bhattacharya accused the BJP of creating a mess. “We had opposed it when the BJP government introduced this divisive policy. We had warned the government that 1985 as a cut off year will be detrimental to the interest of people of Jharkhand. We had a clear cut understanding that on the name of scheduled districts the BJP is dividing people. The then BJP government that cobbled a majority post-election with help of Babulal Marandi hatched conspiracy and played with the lives of youths,” Bhattacharya said. As the High Court judgement has created a constitutional crisis and surcharged political atmosphere the JMM said that chief minister Hemant Soren heading JMM-Congress-RJD government will bring a fresh local residence and employment policy. “The government will soon bring the policy and we assure justice to all. The 2016 policy was a document of fraud and the fraud has been exposed. Das heading the previous government for five years committed heinous sins. The previous government made people suffer,” he said.

head: Tributes paid to UWS founder chairman
desc: Tributes were paid to Unison World School founder chairman, Naveen Agarwal on his birth anniversary on Tuesday. The principal and entire staff of the school paid tributes to him on the occasion. They recalled his role in innovations in technical education in Uttarakhand. The staff also held an online tie and dye workshop with the organization of ‘Devbhumi Janseva and Sadbhawna Samiti’, Kandikhal. Over two consecutive sessions the participants were taught the process of tie and dye and a discussion ensued on how they can sell these products in the market.

head: Kendrapada nonagenarian defeats corona
desc: In what could be viewed as a ray of hope for other people, an elderly person has completely recovered from corona.

head: Budget not an issue for Jal Jeevan mission: Shekhawat
desc: Union minister for Jal Shakti, Gajendra Singh Shekhawat has reiterated that budget will not be an issue for execution of works under the Jal Jeevan mission. Appreciating the chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat for facilitating water connection for one rupee under the mission, he said that this was a unique initiative in the country. He said this while reviewing work under the mission in Uttarakhand with the CM through video conferencing on Tuesday. Shekhawat said that effective execution of this scheme can make Uttarakhand a model state. To prevent budget shortage for this scheme, the 15th Finance Commission allocated Rs 60,000 crore to the Panchayati Raj department of which Rs 30,000 crore will be spent on schemes related to drinking water. Water connections have been provided in 2.25 crore homes in India during the past one year, he added. The CM said that strict instructions have been issued to officials for achieving the target of providing tap water in each home by 2022. They have been directed to facilitate 1,500 connections per day. He said that the provision of water connection for poor families at one rupee instead of Rs 2,350 has been appreciated by the public. By December 25, all the remaining homes in Dehradun and Bageshwar districts will be provided tap water, said Rawat.

head: City forest ‘Anand Van’ inaugurated at Jhajhra
desc: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat along with the Forest and Wildlife minister Harak Singh Rawat inaugurated the city forest ‘Anand Van’ developed by forest department in Jhajhra forest range on the outskirts of Dehradun on Tuesday. Developed as a nature education centre, it provides detailed information about the flora and fauna of Uttarakhand. It will be opened to the public on the first day of Navratri this year. The CM commended the department for developing Anand Van without tampering with nature and using only natural resources. The people should also get a glimpse of the state government’s vision of culture village here. The idea of providing at least a partial glimpse of Uttarakhand here should be considered, he added. Stating that the city forest will also be a tourist attraction, he directed the departmental officers to get a short film prepared on the city forest. Forest and Wildlife minister Harak Singh Rawat said that this city forest is being handed over by the department as a heritage to the society. Theme-based city forests are also being developed in Haldwani and Rishikesh. The target given by the CM to the forest department of generating employment for 10,000 people will be met. Works costing Rs 400 crore will be undertaken this year under CAMPA, through which more than 10,000 people will be linked to employment, he added. Principal chief conservator of forests, Jai Raj informed that it had taken three and a quarter years to develop this city forest at a cost of Rs 43 lakh. Sahaspur MLA Sahdev Pundeer also expressed his views on the occasion.

head: 345 more +ves in BBSR
desc: The Covid-19 positive cases continued to surge in State capital city Bhubaneswar with 345 new cases being reported on Tuesday. With this, the total positive cases soared up to 19,243 in the city.Out of the new cases, 244 were local contacts and 101 were reported from quarantine centres. However, 412 patients recovered on the day, taking the city’s total recoveries so far to 15,354. “Further contact tracing was still continuing. Primary contacts and nearby houses are being quarantined, sanitised and would be under active surveillance,” the Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC) said.

head: Govt running away from discussion, says Qazi Nizamuddin
desc: Launching an assault on the state government for merely fulfilling its constitutional obligation by organising a one day monsoon session, the Manglaur MLA and senior Congress leader Qazi Nizamuddin has said that the state government is running away from dialogue.  Terming dialogue as a key for success of democracy, the Congress leader said that it is unfortunate that the present regime is not giving the elected representatives the right of asking questions. Addressing a virtual news conference on Tuesday Nizamuddin said that issues like pandemic of Covod-19 and failure of government to deal with it, unemployment, returnees during the lockdown, price rise, plight of farmers, recent disaster in many parts of the state, closure of industries, pending payment of sugarcane farmers, pathetic condition of tourism, Lokayukta and preparation for Kumbh are some of the many issues which demand immediate discussion. He said that the BJP government has not fulfilled its promise of loan waiver of farmers. The Congress leader also took the government to task for showing an apathetic attitude towards the Kumbh works. He claimed that the government has made its mind that the Kumbh would not be organised on a large scale in view of pandemic.

head: Farmers block NH, protest farm Bills
desc: Hundreds of farmers under the banner of the Navnirman Krusak Sangathan (NKS) blocked the National Highway at Chandikhol in Jajpur district on Tuesday opposing the farm reform Bills recently passed in Parliament. NKS national coordinator Akshya Kumar led the protest and thanked the farmers for coming out in large numbers against the three farm Bills.Farmer leaders alleged that the Bills are aimed at benefiting big corporate houses and ending the minimum support price-based procurement of farm produce by the Government, said Kumar. Notably, the Farmers’ Produce Trade and Commerce (Promotion and Facilitation) Bill, 2020 permits electronic trading of farmers’ produce and allows setting up of transaction platforms for facilitating direct online buying and selling of farm products. The Farmers (Empowerment and Protection) Agreement on Price Assurance and Farm Services Bill, 2020 provides for a farming agreement prior to production or rearing of any farm produce. A guaranteed price to be paid for purchase of farming produce will be mentioned in such agreements.

head: Punjabi singers extend support to Sep 25 bandh call given by farmers’ unions
desc: Many Punjabi singers have extended their support to the September 25 Punjab ‘bandh’ call given by farmers’ unions against the new farm bills. Around 30 farmers’ outfits have given a call for the complete shutdown of Punjab on September 25 in protest against the bills. Punjabi singer and actor Harbhajan Mann has appealed to people to support the bandh call. Mann, in a tweet, said he, along with several other artists, would be participating in the Punjab bandh protest. Another famous singer Babbu Mann also came out in support of the ‘chakka jaam’ on September 25. In a video uploaded on his Instagram account, he urged people to unite for the farmers’ cause. Farmers in Punjab have been protesting against the three bills. They have expressed apprehension that the three bills will pave a way for dismantling the minimum support price system, leaving them at the “mercy” of big corporates. The Rajya Sabha passed the Essential Commodities (Amendment) Bill, 2020 during the day. It had cleared the Farmers’ Produce Trade and Commerce (Promotion and Facilitation) Bill, 2020 and the Farmers (Empowerment and Protection) Agreement of Price Assurance and Farm Services Bill, 2020 on Sunday. The bills had been passed by Lok Sabha last week. Singer Sidhu Moosewala, in a video, said he stands with farmers who had been protesting against the farm bills. “We will hold ‘rosh pardarshan’ (protest) in Mansa,” he said, adding that he would soon share the details of the protest. He also appealed to people to come out and support farmers in their struggle. A few days ago, singer and actor Diljit Dosanjh had voiced his support for farmers and tweeted, “Kisaan Bachao, Desh Bachao. Kisaan Virodhi Bill Da Asi Sarey Virod Karde Haan (Save farmers, save the country. We all oppose the anti-farmer bills).”

head: Punjab’s 3 Govt medical colleges to participate in phase -III trials of Covaxin from October 15
desc: Punjab’s three Government Medical Colleges will participate in the Phase III trials of the COVAXIN, being tested by Bharat Biotech Limited in collaboration with the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) against the COVID pandemic. The trials are scheduled to commence from October 15. The Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh has directed the Medical Education and Research Department to ensure full care and strict adherence to all precautions to be taken during the trials, for which the consent of the participants will be mandatory. He issued stern directions to also ensure that poor persons are not pulled into the trials without consent, knowledge, and understanding of the possible repercussions and dangers. Bharat Biotech Limited, which had approached the State Government a few days back, has announced Rs 75 lakh insurance cover for the participants in case of any adverse event or effects or death. The possible side effects of the vaccine could include fever, pain at the site of the intramuscular injection, and malaise. Two doses of the inactivated virus injection would be given to the participants (0 and 28 days) as part of the Phase III human trials.

head: If needed, masks will be provided to Govt school students: Gujjar
desc: After the second day of reopening of Government Schools for the students studying in Classes IX-XII, Haryana Education Minister Kanwar Pal Gujjar on Tuesday said that the number of students who attended their Schools was comparatively low but with the passage of time in the next 10 days, their attendance would increase. Owing to rising cases of Covid-19, wearing masks has been made mandatory for the students along with strict implementation of other necessary guidelines. “In the last two days, so far all the students attended their school wearing masks located in rural and urban areas and sought guidance from their teachers. If needed, masks will be provided to students by the State Government,” he added. Talking to The Pioneer over Phone, Gujjar said that the decision of reopening of Government School was taken in compliance with the Unlock-4 guidelines issued by the Union Ministry of Home Affairs. Teachers should go for Covid-19 testing periodically and for this, the health department has made proper arrangements regarding the same. Responding to a question that private school operators criticising the State Government for charging fee from private school teachers for Covid-19 test, Gujjar said that this issue has not come yet before the Government but will be taken care of. The Education Minister said that online teaching would continue in the State. As per reports from the districts, the Covid-19 standard operating procedures were being followed strictly in Government Schools, where students were being thermally scanned and made to wash and sanitise their hands. “The schools opened after six months for “consultation” for classes IX to XII.  Gujjar said that schools were earlier asked by the authorities concerned to follow all Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) issued by the Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and all the necessary arrangements were made for smooth conduct of the schools. A Senior Education officer from Panchkula said that after remaining shut for the past six months due to the Covid-19 outbreak, schools partially reopened on Monday to enable students studying in Classes IX to XII to visit their institutions on a voluntary basis for taking guidance from their teachers. “The State Govt had recently allowed students of Class IX to XII to visit their schools in areas outside Covid-19 containment zones only, on voluntary basis for academic guidance. The students carried written permission that had consent of their parents or guardians allowing them to visit schools for guidance from teachers. It has been made mandatory for teachers to download the Aarogya Setu app on their mobile phones and all were required to take a Covid-19 test before September 21.” A principal of a government school in Panchkula said that students of higher classes, who visited the school to seek teachers’ guidance, were allocated different time slots to ensure only a few students are present inside the school at a given time. She also said that despite education being imparted online these days, as schools are shut, many students were excited to visit the school after a long gap and meet their teachers. “The teachers too were happy to see them after months. Even students were happy to be back in school, even if regular classes had not resumed yet. We were expecting more students in line with the consent forms we had received.  However, it seems parents have changed their mind and are not willing to send their wards to school.  We are taking every precaution in view of the pandemic and following all the government guidelines,” she said. A Govt School teacher said that the attendance of the students was low as some parents might have been apprehensive as coronavirus cases had surged in the State and elsewhere. Teachers were instructed not to share books, dusters, chalks with either students or other teachers.  “We expect more students to join in the coming days, but the decision lies solely with the parents because they should feel comfortable in sending their children to school,” she added.

head: CM to raise issue of augmentation of oxygen supplies from other States
desc: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will review the COVID-19 response in Punjab, which is witnessing ‘higher than national average’ deaths and infection rate. In Punjab, the case fatality rate due to COVID-19 and the COVID-19 positivity rate is higher than the national average. Punjab, which has reported an increase in the number of cases being reported recently coupled with escalating deaths, has CFR of 2.89 percent (as on Tuesday), while the state’s positivity rate on Tuesday was recorded at 5.22 percent. In all, the Prime Minister will hold a virtual meet with the Chief Ministers of seven states, including Punjab, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Uttar Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, and Delhi where 65.5 percent of the country’s total confirmed cases, 77 percent of total deaths, and more than 63 percent of the active cases are concentrated. During the Wednesday’s virtual meeting, the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh would raise the issue of augmentation of Oxygen supplies from other states. “I will urge the Prime Minister to issue the necessary directions to the states of Haryana, Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand, which are currently Punjab’s main source of medical oxygen,” said the Chief Minister. We need to ensure that there are enough supplies in Punjab to save lives, the Chief Minister said amid reports of 14 percent death rate in the three Government Medical Colleges and Hospitals (GMCs) at Patiala, Amritsar and Faridkot, which are engaged in providing tertiary care of COVID-19 patients. The Chief Minister asked the Departments to work towards bringing the death rate in these GMCs to below 10 percent at the earliest. The state Medical Education Secretary DK Tiwari, during the virtual COVID review meeting chaired by the Chief Minister, asserted that while there was no shortage of Oxygen in Punjab at present, “but, if occupancy goes up to 100 percent, more supplies would be needed”. “Nodal officers deputed to monitor the supplies from the three units in Himachal, Haryana and Uttarakhand are keeping the supplies streamlined,” he said. The state Health Minister Balbir Singh Sidhu and Medical Education and Research Minister OP Soni stressed that oxygen should be diverted from industry if required. The state Chief Secretary Vini Mahajan informed the meeting that so far, 10 medical oxygen generation licenses have been issued to industrial oxygen units in Punjab, in addition to 14 medical oxygen repackaging licenses. She disclosed that efforts were on to also procure oxygen from Rourkela.

head: Navjot Sidhu to bat for farmers
desc: Formally announcing his decision to join the team farmers to bat for them against the Centre’s recently-enacted three farm bills, the former cricketer-turned-politician Navjot Singh Sidhu on Tuesday called for taking the movement to the masses. Sharing a video on his YouTube channel ‘Jittega Punjab’, the Congress leader Navjot Sidhu has asked all the political parties, farm unions, and every Punjabi, right from old to the young ones, to be on the same page for opposing these “black laws” till the end. Sidhu, who has decided to come out of his year-long political exile for the farmers’ cause, on Tuesday announced that he would be holding protests against the controversial farm bills from his Amritsar East constituency on Wednesday. His announcement came a day after the party legislators in Punjab, in response to the Congress high command’s call, held state wide protests against the Bills. Batting for formulating a common minimum programme to strategically fight against the Centre’s move, Sidhu maintained that challenging the Bills in the Supreme Court appears to be the best way to counter the Central Government’s decision. “The BJP has got the Bills passed in both the House, and there are negligible chances for the President to counter the Centre’s move…I have also done the politics of solution and not just discussed the problem,” he said. He also claimed that the Bills could not only lead to “unprecedented” food inflation, he said that it would also legitimize hoarding, and the hoarders would sell that produce at much higher prices, leading to food inflation. The former Minister alleged that the Government at the Centre always “went out of the way to help capitalists by waiving Rs 4 to 5 lakh crore taxes and giving subsidies and rebates in taxes…But when the time comes for giving MSP to farmers, there is so much hue and cry,” he said, adding that the GST killed traders. These black laws are ruining farmers. Around 28,000 arthiyas and four to five lakh mandi labourers will also be hit”. Sidhu said that these farm bills would affect the state’s revenue from mandis. He alleged that the Centre was replacing the “successful mandi model” with the “free market model” that had failed in the USA and Europe.

head: SAD chakka jam decision clear bid to exploit farmers sentiment and perhaps even sabotage their fight: CM
desc: Punjab Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh on Tuesday termed the Akalis’ decision to hold a state-wide chakka jam on September 25, the day when Punjab’s farmers had already announced a Bandh against the Farm Bills, as yet another brazen attempt by the BJP ally to exploit the sentiments of the farmers, and perhaps even to sabotage the farmers’ fight at the behest of their allies in the Central Government. “Why don’t you go to Delhi and do a chakka jam outside the homes of BJP leaders and others who have shamelessly sold off the interests of Punjab’s farmers to the big corporate houses for their own petty interests?” the Chief Minister said, daring the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) to quit the Central Government if it really cared for the farmers. Capt Amarinder lambasted SAD president Sukhbir Badal and his wife Harsimrat for continuing to indulge in their hypocritical pretense of standing with the farmers in the face of the blatant attack on their livelihood by the very Government of which the Akalis are a part. “What are these double standards? Why did your Core Committee today not take a decision on quitting the BJP-led NDA coalition?” he asked Sukhbir. Questioning the SAD announcement of holding chakka jams across Punjab “in league with the farmers, khet mazdoors and arhtiyas’, the Chief Minister said this clearly exposed the Akalis’ malicious intentions, since the farmers’ and other organisations had already declared a Bandh for September 25 several days ago, when the Akalis were still busy projecting the unconstitutional and dangerous Agriculture Bills as beneficial for the farming community. There is clearly some malafide intent behind the Akalis’ decision to jump, at this juncture, into the farmers’ pre-planned agitation, he said, adding that the farmers will not be fooled by these antics. The games that the SAD, led by the Badals, has been playing with the farmers for the past several months, beginning with the introduction of the vicious Ordinances, have totally exposed their double standards on this issue of critical importance not just to the farmers of Punjab but to the entire state, said Captain Amarinder. The Centre is clearly out to ruin Punjab, and the Akalis have been actively supporting this agenda with all their might, he said, adding that their purported U-turn or rethink on the issue also appears to be a conspiracy to undermine their agitation. Meanwhile, Punjab Pradesh Congress Committee (PPCC) chief Sunil Jakhar said the Congress, which has always fought for, and protected, the rights and interests of the farmers, stands firmly behind them in the most difficult moment in the history of Indian Agriculture. Punjab Congress MPs and leaders are camping in Delhi, fighting the Centre’s despotic attempts to stifle their voices and bravely facing the brute force of the BJP-controlled Delhi Police, he said, asserting that the party will not succumb to these high-handed measures and will not relent.

head: SAD to hold ‘chakka jam’ on Sept 25 across Punjab
desc: Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) on Tuesday announced a ‘sangharsh’ programme to get the agricultural Bills reversed, including a state-wide ‘chakka jam’ on September 25 as well as a simultaneous ‘kisan march’ from all three Sikh religious ‘Takths’ to Mohali on October 1 to hand over a memorandum for the President of India to the State Governor. The decisions were taken at a meeting of the party’s core committee, which also decided that SAD president would visit various parts of the State to interact with the party cadre from September 26 to 29. “The core committee decided to hold a ‘chakka jam’ across the State on September 25. Party leaders and workers have been asked to hold ‘chakka jam’ in all constituencies in league with farmers, khet mazdoor (farm labourers), and arhtiyas (commission agents). The party will observe a three-hour programme from 11 am to 2 pm,” said SAD spokesman and former minister Daljit Singh Cheema, adding that the party workers have, however, been asked not to come in way of emergency services. The core committee also decided to hold a ‘kisan march’ from state’s all three religious ‘Takths’ (temporal seats) — Akal Takth Sahib (Amritsar), Damdama Sahib (Talwandi Sabo in Bathinda), and Keshgarh Sahib (Sri Anandpur Sahib) — on October 1. While the SAD president would lead the march from Damdama Sahib, former Union Minister Harsimrat Kaur Badal would lead the march from Akal Takth Sahib, and Prof Prem Singh Chandumajr and Daljit Singh Cheema would lead the march from Sri Keshgarh Sahib; and the senior party leaders would participate in the march. The march would culminate at the Dussehra ground in Mohali following which a delegation of senior party leaders would give a memorandum to the Punjab Governor for the President Ram Nath Kovind.   SAD TO APPROACH ALL LIKE MINDED PARTIES After cropping of fissures between its age old ally, the BJP, over the farm bills, the SAD core committee has decided to contact all likeminded regional parties across the country to evolve a joint strategy to forge a united fight to get the anti-farmer Bills revoked.  The party also resolved to pursue all logical steps to ensure the discrimination being meted out to the farmers was removed.   SUKHBIR ASKS CM TO HOLD SPECIAL ASSEMBLY SESSION TO REVOKE AMENDED APMC ACT SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal on Tuesday asked the Chief Minister Capt Amarinder Singh to hold a special assembly session immediately to revoke the amended State Agriculture Produce Markets Committee (APMC) Act of 2017. “The Chief Minister should not practice deceit with farmers by shedding crocodile tears at their fate while he is the author of the same legislation in Punjab and continues to stand by his own anti-farmer Act,” said Sukhbir. He asked the Chief Minister to tell the farmers and ‘khet mazdoor’ of Punjab why he is refusing to rescind the State APMC Act, 2017, which he has implemented in his own State as CM. “Could you show moral courage to disassociate yourself from the Congress’ 2019 manifesto which called for removing APMC Act all together,” he questioned the CM while asking him to apologize to the farming community for encouraging corporatization of the farm sector by accepting the Montek Singh Ahluwalia committee report which calls for reducing procurement of foodgrain. He asked the chief minister to scrap the committee and reject its report which he termed as a death warrant for Punjab farmers.

head: Cong gives memorandum to dist collector
desc: Congress delegation submitted a memorandum to the Collector regarding the demand for public interest including robberies and mishaps in hospitals in the name of corona with the patients. The congress delegation met the collector and gave him a 9-point memorandum regarding the demands of public interest, including the disruption in hospitals and the bill of running into lakhs of rupees for the patients of Covid-19 by the private hospital. Congress spokesperson Vivek Soni said that the number of active Corona patients is increasing daily in the city, there is no arrangement of ICU and ventilator for serious patients in the selected hospitals including the government hospital, Madhav Nagar Hospitals, in the absence of which patients could die.  Apart from this, lakhs of rupees are being collected from patients in the name of treatment of Covid-19 by private hospital, injections are being sold at 8 to 9 times higher which is in collusion with the doctors and drug suppliers and same is done on other medicines. Black marketing is in practice as they do not fear administration; BJP MPs, MLAs are all silent on the issue. The staff in hospitals are not properly taking care of patients. The Congress delegation led by City Congress President Mahesh Soni and District Congress President Kamal Patel met Collector Ashish Singh and shared trouble faced a lot of trouble for the patients fighting from Corona, former MLA Dr. Batukashankar Joshi, State Secretary Chetan Yadav, former Councilor Ravi Rai, Executive Chairman Jitendra Goyal were present.

head: Govt giving full security cover to farmers: CM
desc: Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan, while addressing Cabinet Members before the Cabinet meeting, said that 77 lakh farmers of the State are given total Rs 6,000 per farmer in three installments of Rs 2,000 each every year under the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana. Now, the Madhya Pradesh government, while taking a big decision in the interest of the farmers has decided to give them a total of Rs 4000 every year in two installments of Rs 2,000, on behalf of the State Government. The total amount of the Central and State government schemes will now become Rs 10,000. ‘Chief Minister Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana’ will benefit all farmers of the State. This scheme will prove to be a blessing, especially for small farmers. Chouhan said that 70 lakh farmers of the State are receiving benefit under the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana. Madhya Pradesh Government will give benefit of Mukhya Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana to each farmer in the State after conducting a survey of farmers. The estimated number of land holding farmers in the State is  one crore. Chouhan said that the distribution of the first installment of Samman Nidhi to the farmers under Mukhya Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana will take place on the birthday of Pandit Deendayal Upadhyay. On Friday, the September 25, the Chief Minister himself will transfer the amount in the farmers' accounts from Bhopal and Ministers as well as other public representatives will transfer the amount in programmes, to be organized in other districts. Chouhan said that the Government is providing full security cover to the farmers of the State. Madhya Pradesh Government is taking decisions one after another in the interest of farmers. The scheme was introduced first to provide crop loans to farmers at zero percent interest rate. Then the amount of last year's crop insurance was deposited in their accounts. Today, Kisan credit cards were distributed to remaining 67 thousand farmers, livestock farmers and fish breeders of the state. Along with this, financial assistance amount of Rs. 800 crore was transferred to the accounts of cooperative societies. Now farmers will be benefited under the Mukhya Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana. Soon, credit cards will also be distributed to the horticulture farmers of the state, he added. Chief Secretary Iqbal Singh Bains, while informing about the process of the Mukhya Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana, said that information of farmers to be benefitted will be registered on Kisan Samman Nidhi portal. Patwaris will verify the information in their respective areas. Farmers are required to give applications only once, physically to the Patwari concerned. Further processing will be done on mobile itself. Information regarding amount transferred will be received by the farmers on their mobiles.

head: CM announces Rs 10K per annum for farmers
desc: In a bid to woo farmers ahead of by-polls in Madhya Pradesh, Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan here announced that State’s farmers will now get Rs 10,000 per annum under Kisan Samman Nidhi. Till now, the farmers get Rs 6000 in three instalments per annum under PM Samman Nidhi announced by Centre in the past. “Today I have decided to tag two more instalments of Rs 2,000 each in PM Kisan Samman Nidhi from CM Kisan Kalyan Yojana and farmers will now get Rs 10,000 per year,” CM Chouhan announced in a function on Tuesday. The Congress party had found road back to power in the State in year 2018 in assembly polls with the help of farm loan waiver and is again underlining it’s farm loan endeavour accusing BJP of not letting it complete the scheme. To add, as other States in MP, farmers are also outraged over three agri-sector bills that seek to modernise farm sector but opposition led by Congress is crying foul saying it will end MSP and leave farmers as labourers.Chouhan’s announcement is also seen as a ploy to placate farmers ahead of 27 by-polls in the state. The Chouhan government has recently doled out crop insurance compensation among farmers in the State.

head: 10 ‘trafficked' child labourers rescued in city
desc: The Delhi Commission for Protection of Child Rights (DCPCR) has rescued 10 child labourers from New Delhi Railway Station. The children were being trafficked from Jainagar, Bihar to work in Delhi-NCR and Ambala, and most of them were found unaware of being forced into child labour. They were in unsafe and unhygienic conditions, without wearing masks. The children were rescued by the teams, successfully and provided with masks and sanitizers along with refreshments. A senior government official said statements of the  rescued children have been recorded, followed by medical tests including COVID-19 test. “The children will be produced before a Child Welfare Committee on Wednesday through video-conferencing and meanwhile, they will stay at Child Care Institution at Lajpat Nagar.” Two days ago, in a late-night operation, the DCPCR in coordination with SHO (Old Delhi) and teams from NGOs Bachpan Bachao Andolan and ChildLine-Salaam Baalak Trust rescued six children who were being trafficked from Bihar to work as labourers in Delhi. With the outbreak of COVID-19 and ensuing lockdown, there has been a drastic impact on the income of families. The traffickers have been targeting poor families in Bihar, persuading them to send their children on the pretext of giving employment. DCPCR has taken note of the dramatic increase in child labour during the pandemic and has been working on a fire-fighting mode to curb it through a multi-stakeholder approach, coordinating with all stakeholders including Agricultural Produce Market Committees (APMCs), Mandi Associations, Private Schools Associations etc. of Delhi. The Commission is in process of evolving a comprehensive long-term strategy to make Delhi Child Labour Free by 2023. Anurag Kundu, Chairperson, DCPCR outlined the Commission’s scheme for providing financial incentive for reporting of child labour. He urged citizens to pro-actively report instances of child labour and win cash award upto to Rs. 10,000. He further elaborated that the Commission is building an early warning system to determine child adversity using children’s school attendance as an indicator. It is in the process of laying down processes to activate a series of actions and interventions in the event of children remaining absent from the schools for more than 50 percent days.

head: Signboard of road named after Swami Vivekananda vandalised in JNU: ABVP
desc: The Akhil Bharatiya Vidhyarthi Parishad (ABVP), Jawahalal Nehru University, (JNU) unit has filed a police complaint alleging that the signboard of a road named after Swami Vivekananda in the campus has been vandalised. Police said they have received a complaint and are looking into the matter. The ABVP termed the vandalism a pre-planned attack on the ideologically diverse nature of the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus. The ABVP claimed that a few student union leaders have given an open call for taking down the signboard. According to the complaint filed by ABVP, the members of ABVP are witnessing continuous assaults on symbols of national significance inside the JNU campus. In yet another sequence of the recurring defacement of statues and sign boards named on the personalities significant to our national identity and pride, the perpetrators seem to be persevering, without any respect for law and order. “It is a clear violation of the Defacement of Public Property Act, 2007... We appeal to the police administration to identify the perpetrators and take strict action against them, to ensure peace and decorum in the campus,” the complaint further stated. JNU Students'' Union (JNUSU) vice-president Saket Moon said the ABVP was trying to divert attention from the real issues faced by the varsity. “JNUSU has been demanding that the administration allow a phased return of students to campus and other issues like online registration for the upcoming semester. The ABVP is trying to divert attention from the real issues and are trying to shield the administration from being answerable on these issues,” he said. Objectionable messages, mostly directed towards right-wing outfits, were found written on the pedestal of a yet to be unveiled statue of Swami Vivekananda on the JNU campus last year in November following which the varsity administration had filed a police complaint.

head: Some properties wrongly sealed by SC’s Monitoring Committee desealed: SDMC
desc: Accusing the Supreme Court Appointed Monitoring Committee of ‘wrongly’ sealing of properties under the municipal Corporation, South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) claimed to have de-sealed 173 properties in the south zone and 12 properties in the west zone and said that the process will be continued. A senior SDMC official said that the de-sealing process will also start in central and Najafgarh zone from Wednesday. However, the civic body did not provide any particular areas where the process of de- sealing was carried out.  “Some properties under the jurisdiction of SDMC were wrongly sealed by the Monitoring Committee under the orders of the Supreme Court. Such 604 properties will be de-sealed under this process,” the South Corporation said in a statement.

head: 28-yr-old car mechanic driving Mercedes crashes into auto rickshaw; three injured
desc: A 28-year-old car mechanic, who was driving a Mercedes in an inebriated state, hit an auto-rickshaw and injured three pedestrians in south Delhi's Sarai Kale Khan area. The incident occurred on Sunday. The mechanic has been identified as 28-year-old Alam, a resident of New Seelampur. According to R P Meena, the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), Southeast district, during patrolling at 8.55 pm on Sunday, police found a Mercedes car had crashed into an auto-rickshaw near a Sarai Kale Khan red light. “Enquiry revealed that the car after hitting the auto-rickshaw at the rear side jumped the divider and injured three pedestrians on the opposite side of the road. On further enquiry, it was revealed that the car was driven by Alam and his two women friends accompanied him. He was drunk at that time and some beer bottles were found in the vehicle,” said the DCP. “The accused said that he works as a car mechanic at Seelampur in northeast Delhi and the vehicle belonged to one of his clients who had left it at his workshop for repairing. On Sunday, Alam consumed alcohol and took his two women friends for a ride to Kalkaji,” said the DCP. “He was driving the car at a very high speed. When he reached near Sarai Kale Khan red light, the car went out of control and hit the auto-rickshaw. It jumped the divider and hit three pedestrians,” said the DCP.  “The injured pedestrians -- identified as Brijesh, Mahender and Suresh -- were rushed to AIIMS Trauma Center. However, the auto-rickshaw driver, Sachin, escaped unhurt. Alam was arrested on the spot,” said the DCP.

head: Agitation threat by students of Sikkim college
desc:
The students of Government Vocational College  at Dentam in West Sikkim have threatened to take the agitation path from September 12 if their long-pending demands, including introduction of post-graduate courses and permanent campus, are not met by the state government.
The college, which was set up in 2017 with under-graduate courses in tourism, software development and retail management, operates from a rented building and has a student-strength of 160. The first batch of 60-odd students would have graduated in June, but the final exams had to be postponed because of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Apart from starting PG courses and permanent campus, the other demands of the students are providing facilities like on-the job training, field trips, internships, workshops and industrial visits with financial support and provisions like laboratory, library, Internet and buses.
ADVERTISING
Ads by Teads
“From September 12, 2020, we the students of GVC Dentam are going to start a series of activities to press for the immediate fulfillment of our demands. This will go until all our demands are fulfilled unconditionally,” said the students in a release issued in Gangtok on Tuesday.
The students regretted that despite several petitions to both the previous and present governments, nothing had been done to address their issues. “Despite receiving verbal assurances from chief minister downwards, there has been no progress on the ground. The students have been rendered helpless as a result of the total negligence on the part of the concerned department and the government,” the students alleged.
Advertisement
Powered By PLAYSTREAM
Punyaprasad Sharma, the principal of GVC Dentam, said the permanent campus spread over seven acres was coming up, but admitted to the delay in construction because of various factors, including disruptions caused by the pandemic.
“The construction was started in 2019. Plinth level work is going on,” he said, adding the Union ministry of human resource development had sanctioned Rs 26 crore for the project.
Sharma said since the new campus would take time to be completed, a proposal was mooted to shift the college to a bigger building owned by the government at Dentam. “But the proposal has been stalled because of the pandemic.”

head: Three new faces join Sikkim cricket
desc:
The Sikkim Cricket Association (SICA) has engaged pacer Anureet Singh, batsman Md. Shahbaz Anwar and all-rounder Robin Bist for the 2020-2021 domestic season, including the prestigious Ranji Trophy.
The troika replaces Iqbal Abdullah, Yashpal Singh and Ishwar Chaudhary, who had donned the Sikkim colours last season.
According to the rules of the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI), states can hire a maximum of three guest players in their teams. Sikkim would be participating in the senior level of domestic cricket for the third year running after the SICA was granted full membership of the BCCI in 2018. The highlanders have not exactly set the stadium on fire in the previous seasons, but have been competitive on occasions, particularly in the shorter formats of the game.
Among the three new signings, Anureet has the most impressive record, having taken 249 wickets in 72 matches at an economy rate of just 2.73, including 16 five-wicket hauls, in first-class cricket so far. He also scored 1,209 runs in first-class cricket and played for three teams in the IPL.
Former Rajasthan skipper Bist is a right-hand middle-order batsman and an off-break bowler. He has scored over 6,000 runs in first-class cricket with 15 centuries and 34 half-centuries. In List A matches, he has over 1,200 runs in his kitty with the highest score of 109 not out.
Anwar, who is from Bengal, is the youngest of the three and was part of the Sikkim under-23 team last season. He had a prolific year, scoring 1,130 runs in nine matches in the Col. C.K. Nayudu Trophy, including five centuries and six half-centuries. In the shorter format, he had scored 406 runs in 9 matches, including a century and two half-centuries. Anureet said he was excited to be part of the team and was looking forward to sharing his experience with his new mates and learning from them as well. “Cricket is such a sport where there is always new things to learn. It is a never-ending process,” he added.
Bist, on his part, said he would be bringing in his winning experience, having been part of two Ranji Trophy triumphs. “I am looking forward to the upcoming season and I want to give my best,” he added.
SICA president Lobzang G. Tenzing congratulated the selectors for bringing on board the three talented players. “SICA has signed some of the consistent performers in domestic cricket and we believe they will keep the momentum going,” he said.

head: Woman drowned, search on for siblings in Sikkim
desc:
Three siblings in their 20s from Kazitar Dikchu in East Sikkim were swept away in river Bakcha on Saturday.
Only the body of one of the sisters was recovered on Sunday after a massive search operation.
Police quoting an eyewitness said Chandra Rai, 28, her sister Erika, 22, and a seven-year-old child had gone to the river for fun. They were joined later by the women’s brother Puran, 29.
While frolicking in a small waterfall, Puran slipped and fell into river Bakcha. When Chandra tried to rescue her brother, she got sucked in the water current. Seeing her siblings struggling, Erika jumped into the river. “Unfortunately, none of them knew how to swim and were swept away,” said a source.
On Sunday, Erika’s body was found. Search is on for Chandra and Puran.
Police with the help of residents carried out search operation till late Saturday evening. On Sunday, they were joined in their efforts by the National Disaster Rescue Force from North Sikkim and State Disaster Rescue Force from South Sikkim.

head: Sikkim body ups ante on hospitals
desc:
The Sikkim Progressive Youth Forum has threatened to take to the streets if the government fails to upgrade facilities at state hospitals and ensure free medicine and health services by November 30.
In a release issued on Monday, SPYF said the government had failed to deliver on the twin demands despite the assurance given to the forum by health minister Dr M.K. Sharma in February. "We have no choice other than to issue an ultimatum to the government to fulfill the twopoint demands within Nov 30 2020, else, we will take to the streets," said the forum.
In February, the SPYF had submitted a memorandum to the minister along with 10,000 signatures of the public in support of its demands for upgrading facilities at government hospitals according to the Indian Public Health Standard (IPHS) guidelines and provision for free medical services and medicines to the people. ‘Dr Sharma had assured us that our demands would be fulfilled within two months of the budget session, but the condition of the hospitals continue to remain the same even after five months of the budget session,’ it regretted.
The SPYF said district hospitals apart, even the condition of primary health centres was in a pathetic state. “The condition of PHCs is so bad that people hardly go there. They are only there in name,” it alleged.
The SPYF has been spearheading the campaign to upgrade health facilities in the state for two-and-a-half years. Besides the signature campaign, it had held mass movements on three different occasions. The forum had also organised ‘Gangtok Chalo’ march from Geyzing in West Sikkim to Gangtok in January 2019 to highlight the abysmal condition of the Geyzing District Hospital.
Advertisement
Powered By PLAYSTREAM

head: Ex-chief of Sikkim tourism body held under Pocso charges
desc:
Rup Narayan Rai, a former chairman of the Sikkim Tourism Development Corporation, was arrested on the charges of sexually assaulting a minor girl after he surrendered before South Sikkim police on Monday.
Rai, 53, had been absconding since Friday night after a family member of the victim had lodged a complaint of sexual assault against Rai at the Melli police station. The police had launched a search for Rai in South Sikkim.
Rai is alleged to have assaulted the 13-year-old at his house in Sadam village on several occasions. The girl from a remote village in the South Sikkim had been staying with his family for the past few months to pursue her education.
The police have said Rai has been booked under relevant sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. “He will be produced in a court in Namchi (South Sikkim) in 24 hours,” said Prawin Gurung, the deputy inspector general of police, Range.
The Sikkim Democratic Front, under whose government Rai had served as the STDC chairman, suspended him until the completion of the process of law.

head: Covid protocol breach case on duo in Sikkim
desc:
Sikkim police on Monday filed a case against two visiting technicians who tested positive for Covid-19 for allegedly violating the Covid-19 protocol and endangering the lives of others.
The duo were part of a five-member team from Calcutta and Delhi and visited Gangtok on August 6 for maintenance work at State Data Centre at the IT department’s invitation.
IT secretary Mrinalini Shrivastava sought special permission from the East Sikkim administration for the team’s entry. Granting permission, the district administration had stated that the team would have to undergo rapid antigen test at the entry point, and travel to their places of work and stay in an ambulance under police cover at all times.
During their week-plus stay, the team visited other places and met some MLAs, including Aditya Golay, son of chief minister P.S. Tamang (Golay), and bureaucrats at meetings facilitated by the IT department. Two team members tested positive on Sunday.
The police filed a case against the two under IPC sections for disobedience of public order and endangering lives of others, and for refusing to comply with the government directive under the Disaster Management Act, 2005.
S. C. Gupta, the state’s chief secretary, sought an explanation from IT secretary Shrivastava on the issue.
Since some meetings took place at the Tashiling secretariat in Gangtok, the entire complex has been declared as a containment zone.
The incident created a furore in Sikkim with many wondering why the administration had not acted with same alacrity against politicians and bureaucrats as they did against the technician duo.

head: Don’t derail HIV combat: Forum
desc:
The Sikkim Drug Users’ Forum (SDUF) has expressed fears that HIV prevention activities may have taken a back seat in Sikkim because of an allegedly lax state health department amid the Covid-19 pandemic.
Forum president Rinzing Bhutia said HIV prevention programme should not be derailed despite the prevailing Covid pandemic.
“An emerging public health crisis should not be the reason to derail the handling of an existing crisis,” she said.
Citing an example of the department’s alleged casual attitude, Bhutia said a counsellor attached to the oral substitute therapy (OST) centre at Jorethang Hospital and a technician at the integrated counselling and testing centre (ICTC) at Namchi District Hospital were transferred over a year back, but their replacements had not yet arrived.
Even more perplexing is the fact that the two persons who had been transferred worked for the State AIDS Control Society under the National AIDS Control Organisation (Naco) of the Union health ministry, she said.
Advertisement
Powered By PLAYSTREAM
Bhutia added that the two persons who were transferred had been trained and experienced persons. Such transfers affect the continuity of effective HIV service deliveries, she said.
“Ideally, we would want the department to retransfer both to their original places of posting instead of giving replacements,” she added.
The SDUF president also said her organisation had written to Sikkim health minister M.K. Sharma on July 6 on the issue, but got no response.
“If there is no positive action on the issue, the health minister will be held accountable for any loss of life and the spread of new HIV infections in the state,” she warned.
Sources said Sikkim now has a little over 200 patients under antiretroviral therapy, or the HIV treatment regime.
The Telegraph could not contact the health minister on phone despite repeated attempts.
The Sikkim Drug Users’ Forum initiates community-led action for the health and rights of the people who use drugs.
The SDUF has said that during the Covid-induced lockdown in Sikkim, it has been “tirelessly delivering crucial life-saving medicines to people suffering from HIV”, among others.

head: Sikkim public figure CD Rai passes away
desc:
Sikkim politician, bureaucrat and journalist C.D. Rai died at the age of 96 at his Gangtok residence on Saturday night.
His mortal remains were cremated at the Jalipool Crematorium in East Sikkim on Sunday.
Rai served in different departments of the government of Sikkim during his time as a bureaucrat. Rai had also been a minister in the short-lived government of Tashi Thsering in 1949 when Sikkim was an independent kingdom.
In between and post-retirement, he engaged in journalism and was the Sikkim correspondent of the Calcutta-based Amrita Bazar Patrika in the early 1960s. He was also the editor of Himali Bela, a Nepali daily, and publisher of Gangtok Times.
Rai leaves behind a son, a daughter and grandchildren. His son, P. D. Rai, is a two-term parliamentarian and a senior leader of the Sikkim Democratic Front.
Advertisement
Powered By PLAYSTREAM
